HEADLINE: Through the Roof

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEZIN JONES

 BODY:
SO many new construction projects have been started in East Lyme, so many zoning variances granted, so much discussion of clearing this and building that, that to Bob Gadbois the term ''planning board'' has been rendered almost an oxymoron. 
 Mr. Gadbois, who has spent virtually all of his 63 years in what is still a cozy New England town of 18,000, is concerned about the lingering effects of 15 years of intense development that has seen the town's population increase by better than a fifth, lengthening traffic delays, burdening sewer lines and heralding the arrival of decidedly uncozy businesses like the Super Stop&Shop grocery store.
 But perhaps what puzzles Mr. Gadbois most about the changes in his community is the math that officials use to measure them. 
 ''You go to these planning meetings and they say, 'Don't worry, this will only bring 1.2 more cars.' I ask them 'What's a point-2 car?''' Mr. Gadbois said. ''The same with kids. They talk about 2.5 children. What's point-5 children? I haven't seen half a kid yet.''
 What he has seen in his community, though, is more cars, more families, more children, more taxes, and especially more wealth. According to the Census Bureau, the 30-square-mile census tract that includes East Lyme and a cluster of other communities has witnessed the greatest percentage increase in family income from 1990 to 2000 in all of Connecticut. Figures show that the average family income nearly tripled in that decade, and economic experts say there is every reason to believe that the trend has accelerated.
 The texture of the town is in flux as well. Experts say the flood of new money may be squeezing those in the middle and working classes who have traditionally been a large segment of former farming and fishing towns like East Lyme. For longtime residents of such communities, it can be difficult not to feel alienated.
 ''A lot of people say: 'Oh, you live in East Lyme? It's a ritzy town,''' said Mr. Gadbois's wife, Mary. ''Well, there are some of us here that aren't so ritzy.''
 Resentment of the change may have been evidenced here last year when Democrats running on an anti-sprawl platform were the top vote getters for the town's planning commission and made other key gains.
 The makeover is not limited to East Lyme. Just down the road a bit in New London, a sliver of a neighborhood wedged between Connecticut College and the United States Coast Guard Academy saw the state's greatest percentage increase in home values in the last census. Housing experts and real estate agents say communities in a roughly 20-mile radius around East Lyme, including Norwich in the north to Stonington on the Rhode Island border, have some of the largest increases in home values in the state. 
 ''It's becoming very difficult for people with income less than $300,000 to actually stay in a lot of the communities they've been in,'' said Candace Howes, an associate professor of economics at Connecticut College. ''You've got these old fishing villages that have become the hot new place.''
 The emergence of the nearby Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods casinos and a major expansion of the Pfizer plant in New London have further driven the already outsize demand for quality housing in surrounding areas, including East Lyme.
 ''It's going crazy,'' said Pat Pastor, a manager with William Raveis Real Estate & Homes Services, who said that she had seldom seen anything like the current trend in 30 years of selling homes in the market. ''There was a lull in the business in the early 90's, and then we got the casinos.'' And the lull, Mr. Pastor said, was no more.

The Two Middle Classes
 Sociologists and economists say soaring real estate prices mean it simply costs more for a middle-class family to stay in the middle. Some experts see a widening gulf in the middle of the middle class, separating those who have and those who have more.
 ''More and more it's a case of winners and losers in the middle class,'' said Susan S. Fainstein, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University. ''There are two groups. If you have a secure and steady job, own a home, you can be doing quite well. Then there are all those people who are on a slippery slope who are afraid that they're going to lose their job or that it will go off to India. 
 ''They're the ones who are the forgotten middle class,'' she said.
 Dr. Fainstein said that those most affected by skyrocketing home values in the region are first-time buyers and the young.
 ''The people for whom it's really hard are people just entering the housing market, young couples, people without a nest egg or without parents who can help them,'' she said. ''They're the middle class that's downwardly mobile, because even if you have a decent income, who has $60,000 in the bank for a down payment when they just got out of college or graduate school or wherever?''
 The current tightening of the real estate market in the New York metropolitan region is simple supply and demand. Because there is little affordable housing being built, whatever existing quality housing stock remains is sometimes fought over by prospective buyers with dueling bids.
 All of which serves to price large segments of the middle class out of some real estate markets.
 ''I don't know how people are doing it,'' said Rachel Ranis, a sociology professor at Quinnipiac University in Hamden. ''It's very hard for any family to buy in this market unless both parties are working.''
 At the same time it has become harder for many to enter the housing market, and those who do make it want even more once they get there. 
 ''People's expectations have gotten higher,'' she said. ''Before, we were happy to have just one car in a household. Now, everyone has to have a car. If you buy a house, everyone has to have a room. People have changed a lot.''
 What has remained largely constant, Professor Ranis said, are the forces that drive homebuyers into the suburbs around the region -- the quest for bigger yards, better schools and perhaps a slower, more measured pace of living.
 Professor Ranis noted that another factor appears to be playing a larger role: worry. 
 ''One thing we find is that you're worried that you will be able to duplicate what you've always considered middle class,'' she said. ''The key value is how to keep yourself where you are and your children, how to give them the best start.
 ''There's a lot of pressure on people to keep up with what they're accustomed to,'' she said. ''It's no longer about keeping up with the neighbor next door, it's their own wants and what they're accustomed to.''
 But in the status-conscious suburbs, a larger home is still the No.1 symbol of success.
 ''The ones who are doing well, you see people going out and getting bigger and bigger houses,'' Dr. Fainstein said. ''You look at some of these homes that have closets the size of my bedroom when I grew up.''
 And the reason size matters?
 ''It's the symbol of your achievement, the symbol of your status,'' Dr. Fainstein said. ''It puts a premium on those homes with the center hall and the chandelier and all this space where you can demonstrate your lifestyle.''
 While practically no one would prefer that a community be poorer rather than richer, some experts wonder about the effects of such changes on the character of established middle-class communities.
 ''All of the suburbs that have maintained quality housing have become more and more exclusive,'' Dr. Fainstein said.
 More exclusive perhaps, but also, say some, communities in high-priced markets grow less diverse and its residents less connected socially.
 ''It has a huge impact of community connectedness,'' said Robert Fisher, the director of urban and community studies at the University of Connecticut's West Hartford campus. ''The issue of social connectedness, a lot of that has to do with destabilization. While bringing affluence into these communities, a lot of people are pushed out as well.''
 Not to mention, Dr. Fisher said, those who because of high prices never get to enter some communities in the first place. ''What's happening is that the American dream is a little bit less within the reach of a lot of people,'' he said.

Growing Pains
 Before Mr. Gadbois retired, he worked for decades as a pipe fitter -- Local 305 and 777, he said, even in retirement, still union and still proud -- the kind of solidly middle-class tradesman who was once common in East Lyme. Now, according to census figures, better than one out of every four residents of the Gadboises' census tract reported that they worked in managerial, professional or business fields. And experts say that that number, like most everything else around East Lyme, is growing.
 ''The town has grown so dramatically and the changes are so great you wonder what's going to happen next,'' said Wilbur Beckwith, an East Lyme native and the town's official historian. At 74, Mr. Beckwith has seen much of the evolution of East Lyme firsthand. ''Before World War II the population was about 2,000,'' Mr. Beckwith said, noting that today it is nearly 10 times that figure. 
 East Lyme, formed in 1839 by secessionists from neighboring Waterford and Lyme for reasons that Mr. Beckwith, who traces his ancestry to some of them, said are lost to time, was a place of farmers and fishermen well into the 20th century. When he was a child, Mr. Beckwith said, the town was a thinly populated slice of the hinterlands that made New London, about eight miles down the road, seem like nothing less than a teeming metropolis by comparison.
 ''New London was sort of the car city,'' Mr. Beckwith said. ''Kids from Niantic'' -- part of East Lyme town -- ''were called clam diggers, you know, hicks.
 ''There used to be chicken farms,'' he continued. ''Now, nobody raises chickens in town anymore. And you'll only find the older folks doing some recreational clamming.''
 East Lyme began to change with the growth of the suburbs that followed World War II. The area is home to the United States Coast Guard Academy, the Naval Submarine Base, the drug manufacturer Pfizer and the Electric Boat unit of the General Dynamics Corporation.
 Once a dominant presence with upward of 20,000 employees, Electric Boat laid off thousands of employees in the mid-1990's. The company's post-cold war downsizing was a defining moment for the region. ''It really cut the heart out of the middle class in New London County,'' Dr. Howes said. The jobs now being created in the area are more of a mix, with higher-income jobs at companies like Pfizer and lower-wage jobs at the nearby casinos.
 Pfizer, which already had a base of operations across the Thames in Groton, completed a Global Research and Development Facility on the New London side of the river in 2001. Pfizer officials say the research center, which covers 750,000 square feet and cost nearly $300 million to build, has brought at least 1,500 employees to the area.
 To meet the influx of new residents, home builders have not exactly thrown caution to the winds. According to the town's figures, from April 2002 to April 2003 this community of about 35 square miles averaged little more than one new housing start a week.
 The combination of population growth, new money, low mortgage rates and a modest level of residential construction has made life interesting for local real estate agents like Mark E. Landry, who has been a seller in the area for the last five years -- just about the length of the latest boom.
 ''The business has picked up steadily over the years,'' Mr. Landry said. ''There's just not enough housing to go around to supply the need.''
 The result has sometimes been bidding wars between buyers, with some agents noting winning bids that are as much as $50,000 over the original asking price.
 ''It's competitive,'' Mr. Landry said. ''You're going to get top dollar.''
 Mr. Landry pulled a chair over to a computer screen in his office at Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage on Flanders Road in Niantic and punched a few keys to bring up the entries on the Multiple Listing Service, the shared database used by real estate agents.
 ''This one sold for $10,000 over asking price,'' he said, his finger moving over a thumbnail photo of a recently built condominium townhouse in New London that sold for $175,000. Last year, he said, that property might have sold for $25,000 less.
 He mentioned a burst of new construction north of East Lyme, near Norwich. He fingered a few more keys on the computer and up popped a handful of listings for condominiums in the Norwich area, near the Mohegan Sun Resort Casino in Uncasville. 
 Three bedrooms. Sixteen hundred square feet. All selling for more than $350,000. Even Mr. Landry seemed surprised.
 He was asked what those properties would have sold for a year ago.
 ''They didn't have anything like that a year ago,'' he said.

Drawing Point: the School
 In the next few weeks, Lily Tong and her family will move into their custom-built four-bedroom home in a slice of East Lyme that didn't exist until recently: the Heritage Fields subdivision. 
 A nine-year resident of next-door Waterford, Ms. Tong and her husband, Jim Lua, studied many communities that dot Connecticut's southern shore as they searched for a new home.
 They, like so many others, were charmed by East Lyme. When they did not find an existing home that they liked among the colonials, ranches and splits that make up most of the housing stock here, they decided to build their own.
 ''We felt that this was the place we liked most,'' said Ms. Tong, 44.
 So armed with a $100,000 profit from her Waterford home, Ms. Tong and her family began looking. And once they settled on a location and design, they were willing to wait for what they wanted. For the last eight months, Ms. Tong, her husband and their two children, ages 9 and 14, have lived in a rental property until their home is completed later this month.
 The Tongs are typical of many who are moving to East Lyme. Ms. Tong works at Pfizer and her husband at Anteon, a government contractor in Mystic. With their dual incomes and professional backgrounds, they are emblematic of the upper-middle class infusion here. And as Asian Americans, they are part of the Census Bureau's ''other'' group, the nonwhites, nonblacks, non-Hispanics who, according to census figures, tripled in number in the area surrounding East Lyme in the 1990's. Blacks and Hispanics each fell to about 1 percent of the census tract's population, down from 6 percent and 3 percent respectively. Besides location, location, location, Ms. Tong said that her family chose East Lyme for another reason: schools, schools, schools.
 The high school has become a perennial winner of prestigious education awards and has a sterling reputation in the region. In fact, Ms. Tong said, the school may have played as big a role in her home purchase as anything else.
 ''It doesn't matter how good the price is,'' she said. ''If it's not a good system, we wouldn't buy.''
 The role of the school district in bringing in people like Ms. Tong and her family is not lost on Dr. John F. Reynolds, superintendent of the roughly 3,500-student East Lyme School District. 
 ''It's a neat place,'' Dr. Reynolds said.
 But, often, the district finds itself being criticized for its own success. According to town figures, more than three quarters of East Lyme residents do not have school-age children, making for contentious school budget votes.
 Often the superintendent finds himself having to explain how the benefits of good schools spill over even to those who do not have children.
 ''You have to ask, are we going to have a system that is a source of pride?'' he said. ''Or is it just something that they think is just going to raise their taxes?''
 A rapprochement of sorts may have been reached recently when a measure to construct a new swimming pool for the district was ratified by voters, including many of the town's older residents.
 The key to the victory? It was promised that the pool would be open to all in the town, not just students. Gaining that kind of buy-in, Dr. Reynolds said, stems from preaching an open door policy and budget efficiencies.
 ''We got them in,'' he said. ''And we've got to keep finding ways to get them in. You have to say to folks, 'If you give me a dime, I'll get 11 cents out of it.''' 

Currents of Change
 Besides schools, many here are also concerned about the effects of the growing population on local businesses. Already a Super Stop& Shop is under construction along Flanders Road, much to the chagrin of longtime residents who have been accustomed to more intimate stores and boutiques around town.
 And while some are resistant to change, others like Candy Shapiro, president of Niantic Main Street, an association of business owners, are trying to be like Connecticut birches and stay rooted while bending with the breeze.
 ''We're on the verge of just an explosive market here,'' said Ms. Shapiro, who runs a haberdashery on Main Street called Gracie, Gracie. ''If the smaller stores are going to thrive, they're going to have to find their niche.''
 She said that might mean finding an upscale specialty that caters to those moving into the community. ''Change is always going to be uncomfortable for some,'' Ms. Shapiro said. The key, she added, is ''that it doesn't destroy the essence of the town.'' 
 While the future of East Lyme may remain uncertain, what's clear is that the changes here have made people like Mr. Gadbois uncomfortable.
 ''This town is being developed too fast,'' said Mr. Gadbois, who remains dissatisfied about the town's current course. ''You just can't keep on building and developing without a plan.'' 
 Mr. Gadbois said that much of the development in the region has seemed haphazard. For instance, he said, within just a few miles of his home there are two Wal-Mart stores and two Dunkin' Donuts. ''I don't know which one they want me to go to,'' he said.
 Besides that, he said, he is concerned that some of his fellow retirees who live on fixed incomes are being forced out of the town by rising tax bills. ''I know somebody who had to move down to Florida,'' he said.
 The prospect sends a shudder through Mr. Gadbois and his wife, who have lived in East Lyme all of their lives, save one year immediately after their marriage 40 years ago when they lived in New London while they saved to buy a home. 
 Yes, their roots go deep. And while they understand that they may not be able to stop the continuing growth and development in their beloved town, they hope to prompt further discussion about where it is headed. 
 ''We know that things do change and people have to change,'' Mrs. Gadbois said. ''But when we get to where we want to go, we have to ask, 'Is that really where we want to be?'''

HEADLINE: Sellers' Market

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH MAKER

 BODY:
GRACE FRANJOLA whirled around the spacious country kitchen of a $1.5 million mansion in Roxbury, pouring potent cocktails, passing fancy hors d'oeuvres she had made herself and giving hearty hugs to a steady stream of people coming and going.
 This was no ordinary party. This was a ''cocktail sunset'' real estate open house, the kind of glamorous gala that Ms. Franjola regularly throws to market the many high-end properties she has listed in Litchfield County.
 Besides the swarms of seasoned real estate agents and prospective buyers at the event was another set of people who were there to observe how Ms. Franjola, 51, has earned her reputation for pulling out all the stops when it comes to selling houses: a retinue of rookie sales agents watching her every move, hoping to learn what it takes to succeed in the increasingly competitive world of real estate. 
 ''This woman is a genius, she works miracles,'' said Sevara Jeleva, 42, a former journalist who joined Ms. Franjola's Washington agency, Grace & Co., a division of William Raveis International, in October. ''For me to start a new career in real estate, there is a lot to learn. So Grace is my mentor.''
 Todd Lillard, 33, recently left his home remodeling business to try his hand at real estate. ''I chose to align myself with William Raveis because they are very team oriented and they have a great training program,'' he said. ''Real estate can be horribly cutthroat, especially now with so many new people trying to break into the business, so it's nice to be learning from a true pro who tells it like it is.''
 The number of people selling real estate in Connecticut has hit a record high, according to the State Department of Consumer Protection. As of March 1, there were 15,798 licensed real estate sales people, up 28 percent from 2002, said Michele Erling, a spokeswoman for the department.
 The department does not break down those numbers by towns or counties, but many market watchers say it seems like Litchfield County is experiencing the highest influx of new agents in the state.
 ''We don't have the comparative data on hand, but there is certainly the sense that Litchfield County is experiencing one of the fastest-growing rates of people getting their real estate licenses,'' said Michelle Doyon, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Association of Realtors, an industry group.
 She said there are now 14,000 association members, up from 12,500 in 2002, with 756 in Litchfield County, she said. And while the association lists 73 members from Washington, some local real estate agents have done their own independent count and come up with a whopping 250 licensed sales people in Washington, which means one out of every 11 of the town's estimated 2,750 adults are agents. 
 The slow economy and mounting layoffs have prompted a growing number of people to turn away from careers in law, banking, business, finance, teaching, restaurant trades and the arts to give real estate a try. They're following the money: the real estate market has stayed strong despite the economy because of low interest rates and the ever-growing appeal of country properties. Countywide statistics for Litchfield are hard to come by, but Consolidated Multiple Listing Service figures for single-family homes in 7 of the county's 26 towns -- Bridgewater, Kent, Litchfield, Roxbury, New Milford, Warren and Washington -- show that the average sale price rose almost 25 percent over the past two years, from $314,297 in 2001 to $414,192 in 2003. But some agents say these figures are low, because some top agents in the area don't list their biggest deals. 
 Some top-tier agents in the area predict that 2004 will see a substantial number of $6 million-plus sales. There has only been one such sale in the county, and that was about five years ago.
 But Carolyn Klemm, one of Washington's top real estate agents, has a warning for the newcomers. ''People are very disillusioned about real estate as a career,'' she said. ''It's a profession that sounds a lot better than it is. You don't just go into real estate and start selling houses. It takes years to be successful, and that's only if you work seven days a week, every waking moment, no weekend breaks, no vacations, no family picnics.
 ''A lot of people come to me looking for a job, thinking they can just switch gears from whatever they're doing and get into real estate,'' Mrs. Klemm continued. ''I tell them, sorry, we only hire the top pros.''
 Such was the case with Stephen Greene, who was hired in January by William Raveis's Kent office. ''I called Carolyn Klemm and she said, 'Stephen, you know what? You're fabulous, but you're new. You'd better go to Raveis.''' Mr. Greene said he then called Seymour Surnow, another top Washington broker who did $38 million worth of business last year for Sotheby's International Realty, ''and Seymour said, 'Stephen, you know what? You're fabulous, but you're new. You'd better go to Raveis.'''
 Mr. Greene, 55, who was also at the Roxbury open house, said he decided to give real estate a try after being laid off from his hospital administration job in Manhattan last year. ''I basically just hung around and went golfing every day until I couldn't stand it anymore,'' he said between bites of deviled eggs and marinated artichoke hearts. ''I kept thinking real estate would be right for me because it's about being able to relate to all kinds of people and understanding what they need and what they want, which I think I'm good at.'' 
 So he took the state-mandated 36-hour course (which is offered at more than 40 locations across Connecticut), passed the state real estate exam and signed up with Raveis. And has sold nothing.
 ''No one wants to do business with a new broker, so you can just basically forget it for the first year,'' advised Stacey Matthews, a former Wall Street trader who went to work for Klemm Real Estate three years ago at the age of 33. For example, Mr. Lillard, the former contractor, has to work another full-time job as a bartender to make ends meet.
 Of the typical 5 percent sales commission on real estate transactions, the buyer's agent gets half and the seller's agent gets half, and the agents then typically split half of their take with the companies they work for. ''People see these houses in Litchfield County selling for $1 million plus, and they say, 'Let's see, 5 percent of $1 million is $50,000, wow!' But, if you're, let's say, the buyer's agent, you split half with your agency, and that's only $12,500, and you pay taxes on that,'' Ms. Matthews said.
 ''I think the thing that's finally made me successful at this is years of networking and establishing social contacts,'' she said. ''When you buy property here, it's not just about the house, it's about meeting people with the same interests, who have children the same ages. So I set up play dates,'' bringing prospective buyers' children, and parents, into contact with the neighbors. ''I have dinner parties, I introduce my clients to the people who will make them feel at home.'' 
 One new agent who had no problem joining Sotheby's was Dennis Kyte, an artist and architect whose 32-year domestic partnership with Mr. Seymour made real estate a natural option a year and a half ago.
 ''I'm an artist, I've always drawn for a living,'' said Mr. Kyte, 56, who is known worldwide for his botanical illustrations and the 17 children's books he has written and illustrated. But Mr. Kyte has also designed several homes in the area, including the homes he and Mr. Seymour have lived in. ''My great frustration was that I always loved houses and architecture so much, I knew I needed to be doing something along those lines,'' he said.
 At the encouragement of Sotheby's top executives, Mr. Kyte decided to get his real estate license, and, unlike some newcomers, surprised himself by making some deals right from the start. ''I basically did what they tell you to do in real estate school: I sat in front of my Rolodex and called everyone I know who I thought would be interested in buying or selling a house,'' he said with a grin.
 He knew of someone who was thinking of selling a gorgeous old converted barn overlooking a dramatic waterfall in New Preston, and with one phone call he found just the couple who would fall in love with it. In a matter of days, the deal was done for $650,000, and several sales exceeding $1 million have followed.
 Another neophyte defying the odds is Arnaud Bourgeois of Woodbury. As if his part-time jobs of pilot, antiques dealer and wine consultant weren't enough, Mr. Bourgeois, 36, decided last fall he would sell real estate, too. ''I went to Joyce Drakeley Real Estate because it's right next door to my house and I said, 'Look, I know I'm new, but I know a lot of people. I'm the coach of my daughter's soccer team. I know a lot of New Yorkers who come into our antiques store. I'd like to give it a try.'''
 Two months into his new job, Mr. Bourgeois has already made two big sales. ''Somebody once told me I could sell mittens in Miami,'' he said from his cell phone as he boarded a Gulfstream III for a flight out of Oxford airport. ''But you know what? It's because I care, that's the big thing. I care about people. And finding the perfect house for them is the ultimate reward for me.''

HEADLINE: An Uptown Museum Wonders If Downtown Is the Answer

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL

 BODY:
The Hispanic Society of America, the museum and library in Washington Heights that gets few visitors but is known for its prized works by Goya and Velazquez, among others, is considering options to heighten its profile, including a move to Lower Manhattan.
 Those efforts got a boost last year when Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain requested help from the White House, resulting in visits by powerful Republicans, including Gov. George E. Pataki, who visited in July; Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg; and Mel Martinez, then the secretary of Housing and Urban Development. ''It's about time,'' said Mitchell Codding, the executive director of the society. ''We'd had zero interest from public officials on the United States end. It's good that we've generated some interest.'' 
 But rumors of an imminent departure were exaggerated, he added. ''It's definitely not happening tomorrow,'' he said. ''We've been studying what our possibilities are for expanding facilities.'' 
 After his visit, the governor put society officials in touch with the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, his office said in a statement. An initial effort to find space in Battery Park City was unsuccessful. The Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency, also assisted, and looked into who might be interested if the society's space became vacant. Boricua College, which has a campus in the complex, also got a call from state officials, said Victor G. Alicea, the college's president. ''Of course we're interested,'' he said.
 In the wake of the terrorism attacks in Madrid two weeks ago and the election last week of a new Socialist prime minister, it remains to be seen whether the society can count on additional help from Spain. 
 Only about 20,000 people a year visit the society, which is housed in Audubon Terrace, a Beaux-Arts complex built in the early 1900's. But it has always been a favorite of Spain's royal family: Felipe de Borbon, the Prince of Asturias, visited in 2001. The Museum of the American Indian and the American Geographic Society left the building years ago, and the American Numismatic Society is on its way out. 
 Local leaders betrayed little emotion when asked about the prospective loss of another cultural institution. ''I have mixed feelings,'' said Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat. ''They are a polished institution that gave the community some kind of prestige. On the other hand, they were never really able to connect to the community.'' SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: The Island's Pursuit of Innovation Flags a Bit

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
IS Long Island's Golden Age of Innovation over?
 The region's scientific ingenuity, which gave the world the technology for landing on the moon and the double-helix paradigm for understanding the human genome, reached its peak in 1998, if successful patent filings are the barometer. And it's been mainly sliding downward since.
 That was the one of the findings of a report, the Long Island Index 2004, compiled by the Rauch Foundation of Garden City at a cost of about $600,000. The decline in patents undermines the region's claims for technological eminence and limits its appeal as a center for business activity, the report said. 
 The number of patents issued to inventors in Nassau and Suffolk peaked at 937 in 1998, according to Collaborative Economics, the firm in Mountain View, Calif., that compiled the research. They dropped incrementally through 2001, reaching a low of 786. In 2002, the last year for which data were analyzed, there was a slight uptick, to 795.
 The falloff for Long Island comes at a time when the number of patents has been increasing nationally. From the 1999 fiscal year to the 2002 fiscal year, the number of patents awarded rose about 11 percent, from 159,166 to 177,317, according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. In categories like medical devices and electrical components, areas often cited by business leaders as the muscles in Long Island's physique, innovation actually lags behind the national average, the report said. But it based its conclusion on how often other inventors cite patents by Long Islanders, a measure that raised some eyebrows. 
 ''Applicants cite patents to be on the safe side,'' said Gerald T. Bodner, a partner in Bodner & O'Rourke, a patent law firm in Melville. ''How often a patent is cited doesn't necessarily correspond with its potential value or imply that it's important.'' 
 Oddly, the report cites the textile and apparel industries, effectively absent from Long Island, as areas of strength in patents. And despite the often-noted disappearance of manufacturing jobs, the Island showed more vitality for manufacturing processes than the rest of the country, on average.
 The report was intended ''to bring regional leaders together'' and to encourage ''systemic change'' by creating statistical comparisons with other regions of the country, said Nancy Rauch Douzinas, the president of the Rauch Foundation, which was formed in 1961 by her father and uncle, partners in an automotive supply manufacturing company in Brooklyn.
 Because Long Island's strength as a technological innovator is closely tied, in many minds, to its self-image, any report that dares question the fundamentals of this identity will inevitably be challenged.
 ''I have eight engineers working under me, and we have gained more than 30 patents'' since 2000, said James D'Addario, the president of J. D'Addario & Company in Farmingdale, a family-owned manufacturer of accessories for musical instruments. ''We have 28 patents pending.''
 He cited a patent for an accessory that fits into a bass drum and allows the player to insert metallic rings to alter the drum's sound, and another patent for an accessory that combines a tuning fork and string cutter, used by guitarists.
 Mr. D'Addario plans to expand the part of the business that creates cables used to connect instruments to amplifiers. ''We'd do more,'' he said, ''if I had the time to spare.''
 Mr. Bodner, the patent lawyer, said he was surprised to hear talk of a decline in the number of Long Island patents. ''I'm seeing a lot of small entrepreneurial companies filing patents,'' he said. ''I'm working seven days a week at this point.''
 Quite a few engineers who lost their jobs in earlier recessions and in defense industry consolidations have since founded their own businesses, he said. A number are now pursuing patents on their own and licensing those they have already secured.
 Stephen Smirti, a lawyer who handles intellectual property cases and a partner in the law firm of Rivkin Radler in Uniondale, dismissed the possibility that Long Island's brainpower was ebbing. ''I believe that downward trend is a blip,'' he said. ''A few years from now, we're not going to give that blip even a second thought.''
 Some of those involved in planning and presenting the Rauch report, subtitled ''Setting Goals, Measuring Progress for the Long Island Region,'' struggled to make sense of the findings. Ann-Marie Scheidt, the director of economic development at the State University at Stony Brook, who served on the report's advisory committee, said she was surprised by the Long Island textile and apparel patents. ''I was a little puzzled to see that number,'' she said. ''I am trying to figure it out myself.''
 The report showed other surprising results, including an apparent strength in patents for manufacturing processes. Carrie Meek Gallagher, the report's director, had a possible explanation. ''It could be the intellectual property was created here,'' she said, ''and the actual manufacturing is done elsewhere.''
 Some of the Island's leading business groups, universities, law firms and planning agencies participated in the compilation of the report, including the Long Island Association, the Regional Planning Board, the State University at Stony Brook and the Farrell Fritz law firm.
 Some people questioned the report's choice of statistical comparisons to measure innovation. Patent award figures are, at best, an imprecise measurement, said Daniel Weiss, the president of the New York Society of Professional Inventors, based in Farmingdale.
 ''Patents are expensive,'' he said. ''Inventors don't get them until they have to.''
 Herman Fialkov, a veteran venture capitalist and partner in New Light Ventures, in Jericho, said the sheer number of patents or their frequency of citation were unreliable indicators of economic vitality.
 ''It depends what the patents are for,'' he said. ''You can have a hundred patents, but if only one has a market value, you could be doing very well. It all depends on licensing potential.'' 
 At Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, which has received 170 patents since 1990, talk of any lessening of ingenuity came as a surprise to John Maroney, who runs the lab's office that handles patents and licenses. 
 ''Biotech patent applications have skyrocketed since the late 1980's,'' he said. ''The reason is that the gap between basic research and commercialization has been dramatically reduced by genetic engineering tools.''
 As a result, a research institution like Cold Spring Harbor can contract with a private company to turn laboratory breakthroughs into products that land in short order on drugstore shelves and in hospital warehouses.
 ''This is now a game where a patent means you've hit a home run,'' Mr. Maroney said.
 Over the last decade, the generators of new technologies and new processes on the Island have undergone a major transformation. Not too long ago, the principal players were defense contractors like the Grumman and Sperry Gyroscope, and companies like Symbol Technologies, the bar code innovator, and the Pall Corporation, which specializes in scientific filtration.
 Sperry is gone, but Symbol, Pall and Northrop Grumman remain active creators. Other leaders in research and development range from very large research institutions like Stony Brook, Cold Spring Harbor, Brookhaven National Laboratory and North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health Systems to the very small inventor-entrepreneurs working in their basements or in the labs of family-owned businesses. 
 The patents Long Island gets these days ''are much more diversified than they used to be,'' said Peter Goldsmith, the chairman of the Long Island Software and Technology Network, or Listnet.
 The Stony Brook campus is granted 30 to 40 patents in a typical year, based on research undertaken by its faculty, said Jack Peterson, the director of its office of technology and licensing. Fees collected from licensing range from $12 million to $17 million a year, he said. 
 The big earner, he said, is still Reo Pro, a drug used to treat blood clots. Patented in 1995 and licensed to Johnson & Johnson, Reo Pro has brought in about $75 million in licensing fees. 
 Its inventor, Barry Coller, a professor of hematology who has since moved to Rockefeller University, shares half the licensing revenues with the university, in accordance with Stony Brook's standard contract. ''It's a very generous arrangement,'' Mr. Peterson said.
 Since gaining his first patent in 1998 for a device that secures window glass to its frame, Frank Manzella, a jazz trumpet player turned engineer-entrepreneur, has filed applications for six more patents and intends to file four more. The patents form the backbone of his West Babylon company, Thermo Roll Windows, a manufacturer of windows for commercial buildings.
 ''Once you put the window frame in, it never has to be removed again when you upgrade it,'' Mr. Manzella said, launching into his sales pitch. ''My technology keeps windows from falling in, and it prevents children from falling out. My windows reduce the cost of a window by 60 percent.''
 Mr. Manzella said that after seeing how a better product could outsell its competitors when its features were explained to potential customers, he went back to school to learn engineering, then returned again to learn accounting, finance and other business disciplines.
 ''It's really what I learned from the music industry,'' said Mr. Manzella, who graduated from Manhattan School of Music 40 years ago. ''You want to learn to play classical music, you go study with classical musicians. What you don't know, you can learn. So I learned finance, and I learned to figure out the machines.''
 Now his business is doing so well, he said, that he worries about keeping up with demand. As he put it: ''My father, who was a manufacturer in the garment center, used to say, 'Don't be the fellow with so much business he goes out of business.' I think about that these days.''

HEADLINE: In Philadelphia, Trying to Keep It Real

BYLINE: By MAUREEN TKACIK

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 19 

 BODY:
New York covets the Olympic Games in 2012. Boston won the Democratic National Convention this summer. All Philadelphia wanted was ''The Real World.'' 
 The tale of the city's loving and losing the 15th season of the MTV series, so popular with 12- to 34-year-olds that city boosters hoped it would lend a cool factor to Philadelphia, culminated in a street protest on Wednesday night. 
 By the weekend, the dispute had reached as high as the office of Gov. Edward G. Rendell, a former Philadelphia mayor, who was working to bring the show back.
 On Tuesday, the program's producers announced that they were leaving town three weeks before taping was to start. There had been trouble with the local Teamsters and construction unions, which wanted jobs in remodeling the former bank building in the Old City neighborhood where the ''Real World'' cast was to live.
 In reaction to the pullout, several dozen 20- and 30-year-olds mobilized by a group called Young Involved Philadelphia gathered at the partly renovated building carrying signs reading ''We Want Our MTV'' and ''Show Philly to the Real World.'' 
 ''I've had friends from New York and California, all across the country, e-mailing me about this, and everyone says the same thing: Philly's done it again,'' said Nicole Cashman, a publicist, who represents Yaron Properties, the developer that owns the building. 
 That Philadelphia's battered image would receive a lift from ''The Real World'' is a theme that has been sounded since Feb. 26, when it was announced that MTV producers had chosen the city. The Philadelphia Inquirer made it front-page news. City officials hoped the voyeuristic coverage of seven comely strangers thrown together in a hip pad would help Philadelphia retain more of the 51,000 students who graduate each year from local colleges and universities and tend to move away in throngs. (After MTV pulled out, one protester wrote to an online petition set up by The Philadelphia Daily News, ''Way to keep the brain drain flowing out of Philadelphia'').
 Jonathan Uhl said he heard about the pullout while gathered with eight friends in the artsy Northern Liberties neighborhood to watch the 13th episode of ''The Real World: San Diego'' (in which the hunky Randy, while drunk, makes out with a girl with a fake front tooth, only to avoid her call the next day). 
 ''This just epitomizes what's wrong with Philadelphia,'' Mr. Uhl said.
 The show's production company, Bunim/Murray, had hired nonunion workers to create a luxurious playpen for its cast, as it had in other cities where it taped, including New York and Chicago. Almost from the start, organized labor picketed at the site, at Third and Arch Streets.
 Pat Gillespie, the business manager of the Philadelphia Building Trades Council, which organized much of the picketing, told The Inquirer that the picketing was ''why Philadelphia is a great town.'' 
 At the time, Bunim/Murray seemed on the verge of cooperating and using union laborers, whose wages would have been subsidized by the unions themselves. Then, apparently worried about setting such a precedent, the producers packed up and left. Mr. Gillespie seemed a bit shellshocked at the pro-MTV rally Wednesday evening. 
 ''The venom of some of these television viewers surprises me,'' Mr. Gillespie said. ''They used to say religion was the opiate of the masses. I guess now it's these voyeuristic television programs.''
 But Stephen Starr, whose restaurant Continental West would have provided ''jobs'' for the Philadelphia cast, lamented the turn of events. ''This is one of those popular-culture milestones that Philadelphia would have reached,'' he said. ''There's a few big things that everyone remembers. Like the Republican Convention, or I think the Pope came once. I still remember Kennedy coming and I was 4.''
 At the weekend, an all-out effort to bring back ''The Real World'' had turned political. Mr. Starr had called friends in politics. Sharon Pinkenson of the Greater Philadelphia Film Office, which had spent years courting the show, got in touch with Mayor John Street and the governor's office, urging them to call Bunim/Murray.
 In an interview Friday, Governor Rendell said he had spoken with Joey Carson, the chief operating executive at Bunim/Murray headquarters in Van Nuys, Calif., asking the company to reconsider. 
 ''I just said: 'Listen, whatever decision you decide to make, I want to apologize: there was no excuse for the city allowing that type of behavior from the unions,' '' said Governor Rendell, whose history of wrangling concessions from the city's unions as mayor is the stuff of urban studies legend. Governor Rendell said he expected a decision next week.
 A spokeswoman for the producers, Daniella Cracknell, said: ''Last I heard, we had pulled out. But I think that could change.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: OFF-CAMERA DRAMA -- Josh Sevin, left, leads a protest chant against the decision not to tape ''The Real World,'' the MTV program, in Philadelphia. (Photo by Michael Branscom for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Through The Roof

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEZIN JONES

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE 

 BODY:
ALBERT W. LIAN fancies himself something of a pioneer. Three decades ago, when other homebuyers were making places like Larchmont and Rye some of the hottest real estate markets in Westchester County, Mr. Lian turned his gaze to New Rochelle, a hot spot from an earlier era that had gone cold.
 ''My wife and I were house-hunting and I said, 'Let's go north,''' recalled Mr. Lian, who was living in Brooklyn before he bought his New Rochelle home in 1971. ''I found this place, about 20 rooms. They couldn't wait to get rid of it. Paid $55,000 for it. It was a good deal.''
 Mr. Lian, now 75, put his house on the market in early March. And that good deal? Well, he figures that today his house could fetch seven figures. ''I put a lot of money into it,'' he said proudly. 
 For years, New Rochelle was the place bargain hunters went for a Westchester County address without paying Westchester County prices. (Bargain, of course, is a relative term in a county where a mid-to-upper-six-figure home has long been the standard in places like Scarsdale.)
 But over the last few years, real estate agents and housing experts say, any bargains that might have remained in New Rochelle have just about vanished. Prices there may never rival Scarsdale's, but real estate agents say some New Rochelle properties have doubled their value since the start of the millennium. The relatively low supply of houses available has meant bidding wars, a reflection of the strong seller's market. Historically low mortgage rates have given an additional boost to prices. People who want to move out of the city to the suburbs to have more room and a different school equation for their children have continued to flood to Westchester and other suburbs. 
 One place where the result is seen is in the census tract that includes New Rochelle, which experienced the county's highest percentage increase in family income from 1990 to 2000, which reflects the higher incomes needed to buy these more expensive houses.
 Home sellers and experts say that another byproduct of this real estate boom is that some middle-class buyers are being priced out of the market before they can even enter it.
 Real estate agents say that while a decent New Rochelle house could be had for about $200,000 as recently as half a decade ago, there's virtually nothing left on the market now for less than $300,000 and the typical price is about $400,000.
 While real estate agents almost giddily describe the sometimes-fevered pitch of the market here, some also feel a twinge of sympathy for those unable to jump into a market that had been a refuge for middle-class and younger buyers.
 ''Easy?'' asked Joanmarie Tully O'Connor, the listing agent for Mr. Lian's home, in response to a question about pitching properties to potential buyers here. ''It's easy for us. It doesn't make it any easier for our first-time buyers. Can you imagine what our kids are going to have to pay?''

The Two Middle Classes
 While the forces at play here in New Rochelle are noteworthy, experts say they are not unique. Neighborhoods all over the metropolitan region are seeing home prices rising so sharply that most of the people who live in them couldn't afford to buy there if they had to do it all over again. Sociologists and economists say it simply costs more for a middle-class family to stay in the middle. Some experts see a widening gulf in the middle of the middle class, separating those who have and those who have more.
 In Westchester County, a place that is routinely referred to as affluent, there are great extremes of wealth and poverty, and then, somewhere in the middle, is a middle class whose definition is at best slippery. Nationally, if a family's annual income is $75,000, by most definitions the family belongs to the middle class. By that standard a low six-figure income would put a Westchester family in the upper middle class nationally -- yet that family may well not be a position to buy a house. 
 ''More and more it's a case of winners and losers in the middle class,'' said Susan S. Fainstein, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University. ''There are two groups. If you have a secure and steady job, own a home, you can be doing quite well. Then there are all those people who are on a slippery slope who are afraid that they're going to lose their job or that it will go off to India. 
 ''They're the ones who are the forgotten middle class,'' she said.
 Dr. Fainstein said that those most affected by skyrocketing home values in the region are first-time buyers and the young.
 ''The people for whom it's really hard are people just entering the housing market, young couples, people without a nest egg or without parents who can help them,'' she said. ''They're the middle class that's downwardly mobile, because even if you have a decent income, who has $60,000 in the bank for a down payment when they just got out of college or graduate school or wherever?''
 The current tightening of the real estate market in the New York metropolitan region is simple supply and demand. Because there is little affordable housing being built, whatever existing quality housing stock remains is sometimes fought over by prospective buyers with dueling bids.
 All of which serves to price large segments of the middle class out of some real estate markets.
 ''I don't know how people are doing it,'' said Rachel Ranis, a sociology professor at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, Conn. ''It's very hard for any family to buy in this market unless both parties are working.''
 While it has become harder for many to enter the housing market, those who do make it want even more once they get there. 
 ''People's expectations have gotten higher,'' she said. ''Before, we were happy to have just one car in a household. Now, everyone has to have a car. If you buy a house, everyone has to have a room. People have changed a lot.''
 What has remained largely constant, Professor Ranis said, are the forces that drive homebuyers into the suburbs around the region -- the quest for bigger yards, better schools and perhaps a slower, more measured pace of living.
 Professor Ranis noted that another factor appears to be playing a larger role: worry. 
 ''One thing we find is that you're worried that you will be able to duplicate what you've always considered middle class,'' she said. ''The key value is how to keep yourself where you are and your children, how to give them the best start.
 ''There's a lot of pressure on people to keep up with what they're accustomed to,'' she said. ''It's no longer about keeping up with the neighbor next door, it's their own wants and what they're accustomed to.''
 In the status-conscious suburbs, a larger home is still the No. 1 symbol of success.
 ''The ones who are doing well, you see people going out and getting bigger and bigger houses,'' Dr. Fainstein said. ''You look at some of these homes that have closets the size of my bedroom when I grew up.''
 And the reason size matters?
 ''It's the symbol of your achievement, the symbol of your status,'' Dr. Fainstein said. ''It puts a premium on those homes with the center hall and the chandelier and all this space where you can demonstrate your lifestyle.''
 While practically no one would prefer that a community be poorer rather than richer, some experts wonder about the effects of such changes on the character of established middle-class communities.
 ''All of the suburbs that have maintained quality housing have become more and more exclusive,'' Dr. Fainstein said.
 More exclusive perhaps, but also, some say, communities in high-priced markets grow less diverse and their residents less connected socially.
 ''It has a huge impact on community connectedness,'' said Robert Fisher, the director of urban and community studies at the University of Connecticut's West Hartford campus. ''The issue of social connectedness, a lot of that has to do with destabilization. While bringing affluence into these communities, a lot of people are pushed out as well.''
 Left unmentioned sometimes, Dr. Fisher said, are those who because of high prices never get to enter some communities in the first place. ''What's happening is that the American dream is a little bit less within the reach of a lot of people,'' he said.

Right Address, Best Value
 Carving out a place of one's own has been a part of the makeup of New Rochelle since the first European settlers took note of what was then pristine, arable land here along the banks of Long Island Sound more than 300 years ago. 
 Settled in 1689, New Rochelle was born when John Pell sold more than 6,000 acres of land to the French Huguenots, who came to the New World to escape religious persecution. The town takes its name from the former French Huguenot stronghold, La Rochelle.
 By 1700, the town already had the beginnings of a solid infrastructure - including a constabulary and fence inspectors, according to Barbara Davis, New Rochelle's acting town historian.
 ''It really gave this community a head start,'' said Ms. Davis, who also works as the community relations coordinator at the New Rochelle Public Library.
 And that head start proved vital as, over roughly the next century and half, New Rochelle evolved from a farming community into a mill town and ultimately a resort town by the Sound frequented by tens of thousands of thousands of people from New York City.
 ''So many wealthy Manhattanites came here, saw how great it was, liked it and built their summer homes here,'' Ms. Davis said.
 Toward the latter part of the 19th century, those same Manhattanites began coming to New Rochelle and staying full time. After the founding of the some of the town's earliest neighborhoods like Rochelle Park in the 1880's, people began moving to New Rochelle in droves.
 Between 1900 and 1930, Ms. Davis said, the city's population quadrupled. New Rochelle was reputed to be the wealthiest city in New York State and the third richest in the country.
 Then came the Depression. And while people everywhere suffered, the contrast between suburban life before the stock market crash and after it played out starkly in New Rochelle.
 ''This community was hit especially hard,'' Ms. Davis said, noting that when she combs through city records to trace the history of home ownership in certain areas she would often find only the name of a bank in the space reserved for the owner.
 The city began recovering after World War II, as the G.I. Bill brought in new waves of homeowners and spurred intense development. And since the war, New Rochelle has enjoyed a reputation as less expensive, less homogeneous and less stiff neighbor to more upper-crust communities like Scarsdale.
 ''It's for someone who's attracted to the Scarsdale address but doesn't want to pay that price,'' Ms. Davis said. ''You could get value for your dollar. If you put these houses in Rye it might be $200,000 more.''
 And while the home prices here might never approach those of this city's more upper-class neighbors, New Rochelle residents like Ms. Davis have noticed a perceptible change.
 ''It's really phenomenal what's happened,'' she said.
 The local Orthodox Jewish community is growing, but some real estate agents and others in the community say that the growth here began shortly after the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
 ''It was the environmental issue, the dust, or they had homes in the area'' directly affected by the attacks, said Connie Caglioti, a real estate agent with Oshlag-Eisner Realty. ''Some were planning to have children and wanted to move, some had children, for some it was such an emotional issue that they wanted to flee.''
 Other experts are reluctant to attribute many of the recent arrivals to 9/11. But the economic factors that are fattening real estate values across the nation are still at work here too, defying widespread expectations that the local market would cool.
 ''We thought the housing market would come to a standstill and prices would go down,'' Ms. Caglioti said. ''They didn't.''
 Not only did the high prices remain, some agents say that many potential buyers try to capitalize on the rising values by ''flipping'' properties - buying homes and selling them quickly to turn a profit.
 ''People buy things, flip them and double their money,'' said Hillary Brizell-DeLise, who sold homes in New Rochelle for five years before recently joining an agency in Manhattan.
 ''Real estate is an investment,'' she said. ''It's very utilitarian. It's been the most secure kind of investment. Who knows what the stock market is going to do?''
 Other draws for the market are New Rochelle's livability (with 72,000 people, it still retains vestiges of a small-town feel), proximity to Manhattan (''45 Minutes From Broadway,'' was the title George M. Cohan, a New Rochelle resident, gave to his 1906 musical about his town) and cultural diversity (according to census figures, the nonwhite population in the census tract that includes New Rochelle doubled to 14 percent in 2000 from about 7 percent in 1990).

The Economics of Diversity
 And in this city that was scarred in the 1960's by one of the nation's first major court-ordered school desegregation cases north of the Mason-Dixon line, some agents concede that the city's diversity is viewed as a weakness by some buyers.
 ''Some people will come into the community because they want their children to grow up in the real world,'' Ms. Brizell-DeLise said. ''And some people will insist that they want a community that has more snobbery.''
 Ms. Brizell-DeLise said that the rising prices have not proved a bar to diversity in the city. She estimates that fully half of her clients when she worked in New Rochelle were members of minority groups.
 To be sure, she said, some people, both members of minority groups and others, were priced out of the market by rising home values. But, she said, usually the most relevant color was green.
 ''The prices, when they spike, they close out a few,'' said Ms. Brizell-DeLise, noting that some -- put off by the prices of stand-alone, single-family homes -- choose condominiums or co-ops instead. ''There are some people who weren't able to buy no matter the background because they couldn't catch a deal.
 ''There are people who are successful in all backgrounds and they are happy to come to New Rochelle,'' she said.
 Census figures show that the city has become more diversified, particularly where Hispanics are concerned. While African-Americans and Asian-Americans experienced modest percentage increases here from 1990 to 2000 -- holding steady at around 19 percent and 3 percent respectively -- the city's Hispanic population doubled and sits at about 21.5 percent.
 Citing that kind of growth, the city and its school district play up the more down-to-earth and culturally diverse aspects of their community. The school district - which agents said is a major selling point for buyers -- is a melange, 44 percent white, 28 percent African-American, 22 percent Hispanic. ''And the rest'' - about 6 percent - ''is just like the United Nations,'' said Linda E. Kelly, the district's superintendent. 
 Besides a more diverse student body, the superintendent said that over the last decade and a half the district has witnessed a sharp increase in the sheer volume of students it serves. Since 1991, the population of the district has increased by almost half - to roughly 11,000 students today from 7,600 then.
 That growth reflects the changes in New Rochelle and, Ms. Kelly said, puts a little pressure on the district to maintain its high standards.
 ''Who was it that said the only problem with being successful is that you have to keep on being successful?'' she said. ''But we try not to look at it as pressure but as an obligation.''

Running to Stay Even
 Whether potential buyers are drawn to New Rochelle for its schools, location or some other reason, Ms. Brizell-DeLise said that they might want to act quickly because at the rate values change here, a home's price tag can grow significantly in the months between when a house-hunt begins and an offer is made.
 ''It's sad in a way because people are feeling ready to move and they start looking and by the time they're ready to buy, things have gotten away from them,'' she said.
 That was what seemed to keep happening to Helene Wald. For nearly three years, she searched for an alternative to the place that she, her husband and daughter were renting in Riverdale, only to see the benchmarks for home prices continue to increase.
 ''You think they're going to get better,'' Ms. Wald, 55, said of the prices. ''But it keeps getting worse.''
 She and her family narrowed their search to a handful of communities before settling in Eastchester, not far from New Rochelle. It was a 50-year-old home that needed a little work. But, besides being in a good school district, it fit another very important criteria for Ms. Wald.
 ''It was under $500,000,'' she said. ''And to find that in Westchester County is almost unheard of these days. To find a house in the mid-400's is getting harder and harder.''
 Since the family - first-time homebuyers - moved in last fall, they've been mostly about the business of renovation. New carpets. New kitchen. But they're also finding a range of new suburban experiences.
 ''As an owner, I'm kind of a late bloomer,'' she said. ''I'm learning about gardening, trying to get used to shoveling snow.''

Waiting for the Right Offer
 Albert Lian hopes that the market holds at least another late bloomer or two.
 He and his wife, Joan, raised their four children in New Rochelle in the decades after they first spotted the good buy on Lovell Road. Now, the children are all grown and gone. Mrs. Lian died in 1995, and Mr. Lian finds himself alone with his memories.
 ''I'm sitting here by myself in 19 rooms,'' Mr. Lian said. ''Would you stay here?''
 If Mr. Lian had his druthers, he would rather be at the exclusive Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, where he is a member. ''I used to be scratch,'' he said. ''Now I'm about a 14 handicap.''
 A former corporate personal injury defense lawyer who worked in Manhattan, Mr. Lian came to New Rochelle 30 years ago for the same reasons buyers continue to find themselves drawn to this corner of Westchester County today - schools and the commute, which he found was even better than Mr. Cohan's estimates.
 ''I was in New York in a half hour,'' he said. ''I didn't even get a chance to finish the paper.''
 After retiring several years ago, Mr. Lian noticed that there was a growing distance between himself and his neighbors, some of whom are new arrivals. ''I live in this beautiful house and I don't even know my next-door neighbors,'' he said.
 That distance and the loss of several close friends convinced him it was time to move. ''I'm losing a lot of guys,'' he said. ''Everybody's dying on me.''
 So these days he mostly shows prospective buyers around his proud old home - the antique furniture that was passed down from his parents, the expensive rugs - and waiting for the right offer.
 Mr. Lian said he hopes to remain in the area. He expects that he'll use the money from the sale of his house to buy a condominium. He's not looking for anything fancy. Just something close to Winged Foot.

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe's White Farmers Start Anew in Zambia

BYLINE: By SHARON LaFRANIERE

DATELINE: CHISAMBA, Zambia 

 BODY:
Douglas Watt is part of a most curious diaspora in Southern Africa: prosperous white farmers, vilified as greedy racists and driven out of Zimbabwe, looking for a home.
 Mr. Watt left the country of his birth about a year ago after what has become a common sort of encounter there. The husband of a worker in the office of President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe politely told Mr. Watt that he was taking over his farm and that Mr. Watt had 90 days to get out.
 Today Mr. Watt is one of about 140 white Zimbabwean farmers who have relocated to neighboring Zambia hoping, many say, for a mix of racial harmony and political stability that will enable them to prosper and contribute to black Africa. 
 For the farmers and for the Zambian government, the migration amounts to a new experiment on an issue central to the whole region: how do whites fit in?
 While Zimbabwe has been uprooting its white farmers in an aggressive effort to redistribute colonial era landholdings, Zambian officials, if a trifle warily, have rolled out the welcome mat. They are hoping that farmers like Mr. Watt will breathe new life into the nation's moribund farming economy, which has been mired at the rake-and-hoe level since the mid-1970's.
 For their part, some transplanted farmers say they have learned from their experience in Zimbabwe that they need to integrate, not just prosper, if they want to be accepted.
 Mr. Watt drove around Zambia for three weeks before he found 1,600 acres to lease near this one-street village with a post office, police station and food market north of Lusaka, the capital. Pasture and brush a year ago, the gently rolling land is now five feet high in green tobacco plants tended by 240 workers. Huge yellow sheaves of tobacco are hung to cure in 15 shiny sheds by a new blocklong warehouse.
 Mr. Watt has sunk $900,000 into his new farm, most of it borrowed from a bank and from the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, based in Richmond, Va. ''I have put every cent I have into this,'' Mr. Watt, 38, said, sitting in the dining room of his new ranch-style house. ''I've got more invested here than I ever did in Zimbabwe. We will be an asset to the country.''
 Mr. Watt's move continues a long pattern of whites, increasingly uncertain of their welcome, who have hopscotched around the southern end of Africa in the last four decades. 
 His shift reverses that of his parents, 40 years ago. Back when this Texas-size nation was still called Northern Rhodesia and chafed under colonial rule, Roy and Ria Watt grew tobacco and corn on 4,000 lush acres. In 1964, when white minority rule crumbled and the country became Zambia, the Watts, fearful of their future under a new black-led government, fled to Zimbabwe. Today their son is convinced that his parents bet on the wrong country.
 Douglas Watt describes Zambia as everything that Zimbabwe is no longer: racially tolerant, law-abiding and moderate. It had been desperate for investment after disastrous postindependence economic policies reduced the nation to a beggar for foreign handouts and loans. Critics say President Mugabe's policies in Zimbabwe are creating the same conditions for disaster there today.
 Also unlike Zimbabwe, or South Africa for that matter, Zambia has good land in abundance: about 60 percent of the countryside is arable, but less than 10 percent is actively farmed. In a country of 10 million, there are no more than 450 commercial farmers, including the Zimbabweans.
 ''We think there is a large vacuum to fill,'' said Chance Kabaghe, deputy minister for agriculture, in an interview in a dilapidated office building in Lusaka. ''That's why we have been so open.''
 Still, he added: ''We are encouraging them to respect our norms and mix with the local people. We are watching the situation very closely.''
 For Zambia, the white farmers' money and knowledge may help the nation climb out of the hole it fell into with the decline of its copper mines and nationalization of land after independence.
 Aided by open government policies on leasing and investment -- and by America's tobacco industry, which is underwriting much of the farm-building -- farmers like Mr. Watt are already creating a more modest version of Zimbabwe's once mighty tobacco industry, which has been left in ruins after three years of land seizures.
 Zambia is taking up some of the slack, doubling its tobacco production this year. By 2008, analysts predict, it will produce 82 million pounds of flue-cured tobacco a year. That is twice the yield of that in the mid-1970's, before farmland was nationalized, but still far less than Zimbabwe and Malawi each produce now. 
 Government officials see a new revenue stream of fees and taxes, plus the potential for fertilizer stores, irrigation equipment and maybe even a tobacco processing plant like the one now operating at a quarter of its capacity in Zimbabwe.
 ''We think we have benefited from the farmers who have come in,'' Mr. Kabaghe said. ''We are very proud of them. Our tobacco industry is now booming.'' 
 At the same time, no official here wants the success of white farmers to be too visible, lest it engender the sort of racial backlash that has helped spur Zimbabwe's land takeovers and that is building in both South Africa and Namibia.
 Nor do the tobacco companies want to be seen as the benefactors only of whites. Universal Leaf says it wants to develop 40 to 50 smaller, black-owned commercial farms on the periphery of the white-owned farms -- a move Mr. Rusch says makes both political and economic sense.
 Campbell Dunlop, a 42-year-old farmer, is not certain how it will all work out. He has lived for 18 months next to his tobacco fields in a safari-style hut off a heavily rutted, half-flooded road near Chisamba. But he left his wife and children in Harare, Zimbabwe's capital, calculating that he might eventually go back after turning over his new 395-acre farm to Zambian managers to run. 
 ''I haven't got my head around making this home,'' he said.
 Like many of his compatriots here, Mr. Dunlop is haunted by his losses in Zimbabwe. He and other migrants say they find comfort as far-flung neighbors, united by their two-way radios, their memories of 90-day eviction notices and their sense of outrage over the lack of world reaction to Mr. Mugabe.
 A few of their old workers have followed them. Dzingai Kapondoro, 33, worked for 15 years for a white tobacco farmer in Zimbabwe. After Mr. Mugabe's forces evicted the farmer and carved up the farm, Mr. Kapondoro's delighted family were the proud new owners of 25 acres. But while he had skills, Mr. Kapondoro said, he had no equipment to till the land or money for fertilizer and seed. With 25 acres of barren farmland and no income, he finally followed the farm's former white manager to Mr. Dunlop's farm in Zambia. Now he grades tobacco and lives in a thatched hut hundreds of miles from his wife and four children.
 Douglas Watt says it is a relief, a joy even, to feel welcome again. Barely a year ago, during his final days as a Zimbabwe farmer, he recalled, his own workers barricaded him and his wife in their farmhouse for 18 hours. 
 With shouts and a clamor of drums, they demanded that he make good on the Mugabe government's promise of compensation for the fact that the Watts' forced eviction from their farm would leave them jobless.
 During his first weeks in Zambia last year, his workers raised a different sort of ruckus. They were celebrating the first time in their lives that many of them had been paid.
 ''You could hear the party across the river,'' he said. ''The drums beat for two days. It was actually a wonderful feeling.''
