HEADLINE: $6 Billion Loan Deal by Freddie Mac Examined by U.S.

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
The Department of Housing and Urban Development is examining an unusual $6 billion deal made last year by Freddie Mac to fulfill its federal requirements on loans for affordable housing.
 In the transaction, Freddie Mac agreed to guarantee and securitize, or turn into bonds, about 8,000 mortgages on small apartment buildings, loans made by Washington Mutual, the sixth-largest American bank. 
 Guaranteeing and securitizing loans is an important part of Freddie Mac's business. Like its larger corporate cousin, Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac is a government-sponsored finance company created to encourage home ownership by lowering mortgage rates. Together, the two companies own or guarantee almost half of the home loans in the United States. Critics of Freddie and Fannie, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, say the companies have become too big and pose a risk to taxpayers because the federal government implicitly backs their debt. 
 In a typical deal, Freddie Mac takes loans from a bank or mortgage company and issues mortgage-backed securities whose interest payments it guarantees, even if the original borrowers default. In return, Freddie Mac takes a slice of the interest that is paid by the borrower.
 But in the big deal last year, Freddie Mac agreed to pay Washington Mutual $100 million for the right to guarantee and securitize the mortgages. Normally, Freddie and Fannie do not pay banks for the right to securitize loans, but for the loans themselves.
 ''This is a pretty unique transaction,'' said David Palombi, a spokesman for Freddie Mac.
 Washington Mutual disclosed in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission for 2003 that it had the right to undo the deal, completed last October, without a penalty. In other words, if Washington Mutual decides that it wants the mortgages back for any reason, it can take them back. In its annual report, Washington Mutual said the mortgages remained on its books because it still controlled them.
 ''Since the company has the unilateral right to collapse the securities after one year, the company has effectively retained control over the loans,'' Washington Mutual said. ''Accordingly, the assets continue to be accounted for and reported as loans.''
 The report raises the question of what, if any, economic value Freddie Mac received in return for the $100 million it paid to Washington Mutual. But Freddie had another reason to buy the loans.
 Federal regulations require that Fannie and Freddie support affordable housing, and last year the Department of Housing and Urban Development specifically encouraged the companies to buy loans on apartment buildings with 5 to 50 units. Each housing unit in a building of that size counted for two units toward Freddie's affordable housing goal, according to Mr. Palombi.
 ''The transaction facilitated meeting the 2003 affordable housing goals,'' Mr. Palombi said. In all, Freddie bought about $22.6 billion in mortgages for multifamily homes and apartment buildings in 2003, according to Douglas Robinson, another Freddie spokesman.
 The Washington Mutual deal also gave Freddie Mac an entree into the market for mortgages for apartment buildings, which the company views as a business with strong potential, Mr. Palombi said. ''We've marked ourselves as a player in this market,'' he said.
 But the transaction has caught the attention of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. John C. Weicher, assistant secretary of the department, said in an e-mail message to a spokesman that he thought the deal was not typical.
 ''HUD is looking into the details of the WAMU transaction to ensure that housing units associated with the transaction are eligible for credit under HUD's regulation,'' Mr. Weicher said. (WAMU refers to Washington Mutual.) Mr. Weicher declined to comment on what parts of the deal his department was examining.
 Fannie Mae has not made such agreements, said Chuck Greener, a spokesman for Fannie Mae. ''We have not done a deal like this where we paid a fee to a lender to induce them to swap us loans for housing goal purposes,'' Mr. Greener responded in an e-mail message.
 The inquiry comes as Freddie Mac is working to restore its credibility with lawmakers and regulators after a difficult 2003. In the last nine months, Freddie has ousted its chief executive and has admitted that it hid about $5 billion in profits so that it could use those gains to bolster its earnings in the future.

HEADLINE: Shares Off a Bit on Profit Taking From Thursday Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The rally on Wall Street lost momentum amid profit taking yesterday, leaving stocks narrowly lower, but still allowing the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite index to post weekly gains for the first time since early March. 
 Investors were initially reassured by the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, which rose to 95.8 in March, from 94.4 in February. The increase could mean consumers may be willing to spend more, bolstering the economy.
 A continued daily dose of strong economic reports and earnings could ignite the buying that Wall Street has been waiting for, Brian Belski, market strategist at Piper Jaffray, said. 
 ''The market looks like it wants to rally into earnings and throughout the earnings season, and we could be back to focusing on inherent fundamentals like earnings and valuation,'' Mr. Belski said. ''We're in a day-to-day, micro-reactive market that jumps on each little bit of news. If that news continues to be positive, we're in good shape.''
 The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.85 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,212.97, after a 170.59 point gain on Thursday.
 Broader stock indicators were also modestly lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 1.13 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,108.06, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 7.15 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,960.02. 
 For the week, the Dow climbed 26.37 points, or 0.3 percent, and the Nasdaq rose 19.55 points, or 1.0 percent, while the S.&P. 500 lost 1.72 points, or 0.2 percent. 
 The Dow and Nasdaq halted a steep two-week decline, largely because of Thursday's gains, while the S.&P. 500 had its third consecutive losing week.
 The Commerce Department report on consumer income and spending, while not entirely positive, was still good enough to support the Michigan findings. Consumer income rose 0.4 percent in February, up from the 0.3 percent rise reported in January and slightly better than economists expected.
 However, consumer spending rose 0.2 percent, down from the 0.5 percent gain in January. While less than Wall Street expected, consumer spending still managed to make gains, analysts said, showing that the recent economic troubles have not deterred consumers. 
 The biggest coming indicator, however, is next week's payroll report for March, which analysts are hoping will be better than expected.
 ''If we get any kind of upside surprise in the jobs report, this market's really going to take off,'' Mr. Belski said.
 Until then, however, the stock markets will probably remain somewhat stagnant unless another major, unexpected world event occurs.
 ''The market is going to be a wait-and-see pattern until we get payroll and earnings,'' said Keith Keenan, vice president of institutional trading at Wall Street Access. 
 E*Trade Financial gained 40 cents, to $13.10, after the company was added to the S.&P. 500 index. The online brokerage and banking company was also upgraded to strong buy by Raymond James.
 Hewlett-Packard filed suit against a rival computer maker, Gateway, contending infringement of six patents covering a variety of personal computer technologies. Hewlett fell 3 cents, to $22.36, while Gateway dropped 14 cents, to $5.26.
 EchoStar Communications posted earnings that came in 8 cents a share below analysts' estimates, as well as lower-than-expected revenue. EchoStar slumped 94 cents, to $33.70.
 Treasury prices fell yesterday with the 10-year note declining 24/32, to a price of 101 12/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, jumped to 3.83 percent from 3.74 percent on Thursday.
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 15/32, to 109 8/32. The bond's yield rose to 4.77 percent, from 4.69 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Japanese Household Spending Rises for 4th Month in a Row

BYLINE: By TODD ZAUN

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 26 

 BODY:
Spending by Japanese households rose for a fourth consecutive month in February, the government said Friday, offering evidence that a recovery driven so far mostly by exports is beginning to catch on with consumers. 
 The strong figures were the latest of a string of upbeat reports about the economy. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 2.08 percent, to its highest level in 21 months. 
 Average spending by households of wage earners, a closely watched measure of personal consumption, increased 6.9 percent in February from a year earlier, as Japanese spent more in restaurants and on cars. 
 ''This was clearly stronger than expected,'' said Ryo Hino, economist with J.P. Morgan in Tokyo. ''The trend, for the first quarter at least, is looking pretty good.''
 The government also reported that retail sales rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, the second consecutive month of gains.
 Japan's economy has been through a number of false starts in recent years, with export-led recovery fizzing out because consumer spending failed to catch on. Just as in the United States, Japan's economic recovery has not yet generated the broad growth in jobs and incomes that might fuel a stronger rebound in consumption.
 Driven mostly by strong demand for Japanese products in the United States, Europe and Asia, the Japanese economy grew at a 6.4 percent annual pace in the last quarter of 2003, its best performance since the collapse of the land and stock bubble in the early 1990's. And with corporate profits rising, the threat of layoffs is subsiding and consumers say they are less worried than they once were about the economy.
 ''I think it's definitely getting better,'' said Kotomi Yokoyama, 35. Ms. Yokoyama said that her husband, who works for a real estate company, was earning more than ever so they were spending more on tutors for their two children, hoping to improve their chances of getting into good schools.
 Over all, however, salaries are still falling as manufacturers remain under pressure to cut costs to compete with producers in China. And while the rising stock market has increased household wealth somewhat, those gains have been more than offset by a drop in real estate prices that has eroded home values.
 ''There is a certain core of improvement that the reports are revealing,'' said Jeffrey Young, an economist with Nikko Citigroup. But he warned that ''there are still strong headwinds for the household sector.''
 ''We're more than two years into the economic cycle and incomes have not risen yet,'' he added.
 Another note of caution in the data came from the fact that about half of the rise in spending resulted from February 2004 being a day longer than February 2003.
 Still, even after adjusting for the leap-year effect, the spending number was encouraging, many economists said.
 The figures released Friday also showed that Japan continued to struggle with deflation. The nationwide consumer price index was flat in February from a year earlier, the government reported, while the price index for the Tokyo area fell 0.1 percent in March from a year ago, extending the string of declines in that number to four and a half years.

HEADLINE: Above All, Money Matters Are What Matter to Poles

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 25 

 BODY:
Poles are more than aware that this is a dizzying moment. Just a month before they shuck off the last traces of their Communist past by joining the European Union, their government is collapsing and they worry that, like Spain, their friendship with the United States may provoke a terror attack against them.
 Yet there are no big demonstrations against -- or for -- the war in Iraq. There is little public outcry against -- and certainly not for -- Leszek Miller, the nearly finished prime minister. There is not even much jubilation that Poland will enter the European Union as the biggest and most influential of the 10 new nations in the club. 
 Instead, for the moment, Poles seem quietly dug in, waiting with anticipation -- and a touch of their inborn conservative pessimism -- to see just what all this change brings.
 ''Nothing has really happened so far,'' said Piotr Bartosz, 34, owner of a small electronics shop in a run-down market here in the capital. Things are moving around but it hasn't touched us yet.''
 A recent rebound in a long-stifled economy, combined with fears that the European Union will actually make life harder in the short term, have left people focused on their pocketbooks -- with little left over, experts say, for larger issues like Mr. Miller's fall or Iraq.
 ''Life centers around the economy, around wages, around what they can or cannot buy with their money, and they can buy more and more,'' said Zbigniew Lewicki, professor of American studies at Warsaw University.
 ''The government is so alienated from the public,'' he added, ''people don't pay much attention to it.''
 Unemployment, which has hit a record high of nearly 21 percent, is one major reason for the decline of Mr. Miller, who look office in 2001. Today his popularity stands at just about 10 percent.
 More devastating, perhaps, are the corruption scandals that eroded his credibility -- a fact he acknowledged in an interview this week when he spoke vaguely of ''various crimes'' attributed to party members ''especially on the local level.''
 ''This is simply sort of a label that was glued to us,'' he said. ''And it has to bring about negative responses.''
 Many members of his own party have been more blunt about where they believe blame lies, as they announced this week that they would form a new party without Mr. Miller. 
 ''Leszek Miller has lost society's trust and most certainly has to leave,'' Marek Borowski, the Parliament speaker, told reporters this week. 
 [On Friday, Mr. Miller announced his resignation, effective May 2, the day after Poland officially joins the European Union.]
 Unlike in Spain, however, the war in Iraq did not seem to contribute to Mr. Miller's fall, though Poland has deep reservations about it. Opinion surveys show that, as in Spain, most Poles oppose having troops in Iraq, and fear has spiked since the bombings in Madrid this month that terrorists may single out Poland as one of America's closest allies. It has one of the largest allied contingents in Iraq, with 2,500 troops there.
 ''I think it's putting people in danger unnecessarily,'' said Jan Wieczorek, 54, a grocer in the Warsaw market.
 Poles are also upset that the United States has not reciprocated their support by allowing them to travel to America without visas, and they feel ''misled,'' as President Alexander Kwasniewski said last week, that unconventional weapons have not been found in Iraq.
 But the nation remains deeply warm to the United States, and Poland will still enter the European Union as one of its most pro-American members, changing the European mix even as Poland itself is changed. Already the little market where Mr. Bartosz and Mr. Wieczorek work is one symbol of both the worry and the hope that Poles see in joining the European club.
 Huge foreign supermarkets with low prices have cut business in this market, which has provided the neighborhood meat, vegetables, sweets and clothes for at least 30 years.
 The market was never pretty, built with rusty tin siding, but it has looked especially shabby since the fancy modern building of a computer and mobile phone company opened across the street. Shopkeepers have agreed to spruce the market up.
 Teresa Lendzion, 28, whose husband's family sells a dozen varieties of apples and pears there, said they had felt the crunch of low supermarket prices. She fears the European Union will bring more big foreign stores.
 Still, she said, joining is the right way ahead, even if, like most Poles, she does not seem to see this as a moment to celebrate.
 ''I think we have chances,'' she said tentatively. ''I think there are possibilities, especially for young people. The borders will open and they can go work somewhere.''

HEADLINE: Economy Is the Star of the Campaign Trail as Bush and Kerry Court Voters

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN and ROBERT PEAR; Jodi Wilgoren reported from Warren for this article and Robert Pear from Phoenix.

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., March 26 

 BODY:
The presidential race turned squarely to the economy on Friday, as Senator John Kerry courted this hard-hit state with a promise of new jobs, while President Bush promoted his tax cuts as an engine for growth.
 After several weeks of being portrayed as a tax-and-spend liberal in advertisements by the Bush campaign, Mr. Kerry used his first major policy address of the general election battle to position himself as a moderate New Democrat on fiscal policy. He proposed an overhaul of corporate taxes that would provide a 5 percent reduction in the corporate tax rate for most companies. 
 Mr. Bush, after days of focus in Washington on his administration's response to terrorism, spent the day defending his economic record after a period of recession and extolling homeownership as he traveled in the fast-growing states of Arizona and New Mexico.
 For Mr. Kerry, it was a critical moment of self-definition on the economy, which many political strategists see as the top issue in the unfolding campaign. He plans to outline a variety of economic proposals in a spring offensive under the new banner ''Jobs First.''
 ''Under this president, more and more of our people have begun to lose confidence in our economy,'' Mr. Kerry said in a speech at Wayne State University in Detroit, ticking off dire statistics about unemployment and poverty over the past three years. ''Instead of giving us an economy that creates jobs and opportunity, our present leadership has given us wedge issues designed to divide Americans. Instead of a real economic plan, they have given us the old politics of negative attacks.''
 But Mr. Bush used his visit to the Southwest to highlight the record levels of homeownership there and across the country, arguing that his tax cuts had spurred the economy by increasing demand.
 ''This economy is strong, and it's getting stronger,'' Mr. Bush told an audience of several hundred at the sun-splashed courtyard at the state fairgrounds in Albuquerque. Later, speaking to members of the carpenters' union in Phoenix, he said, ''The most important issue for me is jobs.'' The parallel campaign swings two time zones apart were part of a debate over the economy that will play out across the campaign year. Mr. Kerry plans two more major speeches on the economy in the coming weeks, each intended to back up his promise to create 10 million new jobs in his first term, if elected.
 Mr. Kerry brought out members of the Clinton administration to pitch his plan on Friday, hoping people will link his campaign to the thriving 1990's economy. Roger Altman, Mr. Clinton's deputy treasury secretary, held a conference call with reporters, while Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's top economic adviser, traveled with the campaign and did the rounds on television.
 ''It is completely achievable for the United States to return to a path of creating 10 million jobs in four years,'' Mr. Sperling told reporters flying with Mr. Kerry from Washington to Detroit, noting that the Clinton administration added 11 million jobs in its first term. The corporate tax overhaul Mr. Kerry announced Friday would end provisions in the tax code that allow American companies to take tax deferments on profits earned overseas. That is expected to yield about $11 billion annually.
 To encourage companies to bring back the $600 billion invested abroad, Mr. Kerry would provide a one-year haven in which those profits would be taxed at 10 percent rather than the full rate. Mr. Sperling said he thought that would bring a one-time windfall of $10 billion to $20 billion.
 Mr. Sperling said just 6,000 companies, or less than 1 percent of the total, have foreign operations and would be affected by those changes. For the rest, Mr. Kerry is promising a reduction in the corporate tax rate to 33.25 percent from 35 percent, and a tax credit exempting them from payroll taxes on any new jobs created over two years.
 ''Some may be surprised to hear a Democrat calling for lower corporate tax rates,'' Mr. Kerry said at Wayne State before heading to this suburb for a rally with auto workers. ''The fact is, I don't care about the old debates. I care about getting the job done and creating jobs here in the United States of America.''
 Scott McClellan, the White House press secretary, scoffed at the tax plan proposed by Mr. Kerry.''Reshuffling of the tax code, while increasing taxes on small businesses and entrepreneurs, does nothing to create an environment for sustained economic growth and job creation,'' Mr. McClellan told reporters traveling with the president.
 In appearances in New Mexico and Arizona, two swing states, President Bush tried to deflect criticism from Mr. Kerry and other Democrats that the administration had been passive as companies shifted tens of thousands of American jobs to other countries. He called for permanent extension of his tax cuts and a reduction in government regulations and paperwork.
 ''The best way to make sure people can find work in America is to make sure the business environment, the entrepreneurial environment is strong and solid,'' Mr. Bush said. ''If you want to keep jobs here in America, we need less paperwork.''
 Mr. Bush said he would push to make high-speed Internet service available in all parts of the country by 2007, and said consumers should have ''plenty of choices when it comes to purchasing the broadband carrier.'' He added, ''Congress must not tax access to broadband technology if we want to spread it around.'' 
 He also criticized Democrats for trade policies he portrayed as protectionist. ''Instead of walling each other off, like the economic isolationists want us to do,'' he said, Americans should have confidence in their ability to compete in world markets. ''Economic isolationism will lead to economic stagnation,'' he declared.
 Aware of these accusations, which Mr. Bush has made several times since Mr. Kerry became his party's presumptive nominee, Mr. Kerry insisted in his Detroit speech, ''I am not a protectionist, but I am a competitor,'' saying he would modify trade agreements to require worker and environmental protections.
 The Kerry campaign also entered the debate over Mr. Bush's jokes on Wednesday night at a dinner with journalists in Washington, where he showed slides of himself searching under his desk, among other places for weapons of mass destruction.
 ''If George Bush thinks his deceptive rationale for going to war is a laughing matter, then he's even more out of touch than we thought,'' the campaign said in a statement on its Web site. The White House has said Mr. Bush was not making light of the war in Iraq, but was engaging in self-deprecating humor as is the custom at such dinners.

HEADLINE: In Connecticut, No Solutions So Far for Jammed Roadways

BYLINE: By PAUL von ZIELBAUER

 BODY:
The chaos created by a fuel-truck crash Thursday night in Bridgeport underscored how much must still be done -- and how little, relatively speaking, has been accomplished -- to relieve what experts say is an interstate highway system in crisis in southwestern Connecticut. 
 The problem facing elected officials, local residents and regional transportation planners is daunting: how do you reduce congestion on an aging highway in the heart of the state's most crowded, affluent and economically important region without crippling the residents, governments and companies that depend on it? 
 In a region where Interstate 95 already cuts through several crowded downtowns and connects to hundreds of suburban feeder roads, expanding major sections of the highway is virtually impossible, traffic experts say. 
 Though more lanes are being built in some sections, including the snaking bottleneck in Bridgeport where the truck accident occurred on Thursday, ''it seems pretty implausible'' to expand the entire interstate, said Robert Wilson, the executive director of the South Western Regional Planning Agency, a nonprofit group based in Stamford. 
 ''There's not enough money for the system now,'' he said, ''not to mention for an additional roadway that no one would want anyway.''
 Enlarging the busiest portion of Interstate 95 in Connecticut, between Greenwich and New Haven, has been mentioned by state transportation officials in the past, but the idea quickly -- and appropriately -- died, said Carmine Trotta, a manager for the Connecticut Department of Transportation. 
 ''The area is developed so much, and the cost would be so extensive, and the environmental impact would be so great that we essentially abandoned the idea,'' he said in an interview Friday. 
 Moreover, Mr. Trotta said, ''the cost would be billions.''
 More recently, during a meeting of the state Transportation Strategy Board, a group of business leaders and state commissioners, someone suggested ''seriously exploring double-decking I-95,'' Mr. Wilson said. That idea, too, was promptly discarded. 
 Thus, for a number of geographic, historical and lifestyle reasons, plowing into a daily crawl on Interstate 95 to and from work is the only real option for thousands of daily commuters who shun the region's under-funded and often inconvenient public transportation options. 
 ''It's a geographic issue,'' said Mr. Wilson, of the South Western Regional Planning Agencv, because the state Capitol is in Hartford, where too many lawmakers ''don't recognize rail as an option, because in that part of the state there are no commuter railroads.'' 
 Many state officials acknowledge that the state's commuter train line -- Connecticut owns the railroad tracks and some 350 train cars on the New Haven line of Metro-North -- is prone to frustrating delays and breakdowns, and that the current level of service is no way to lure commuters off highways.
 For many commuters, the only alternative to using Interstate 95 to get to and from work is the Merritt Parkway, which runs roughly parallel to Route I-95 from Greenwich to Stratford and is off limits to large trucks. 
 Expanding the Merritt's capacity, however, is also out of the question. In 1991, the roadway, built mostly in the 1920's and 1930's, was added to the National Register of Historic Places. Replacing even the road's wooden guard rails requires approval from federal preservationists. 
 ''There is little support for widening that roadway,'' Mr. Trotta said, although, unlike Interstate 95, ''there is enough property to do so.''

HEADLINE: The West Side's Yours, Ground Zero Mine

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
It is not exactly a municipal version of Yalta. But through a deal made for two politicians with pressing political needs, shared electoral constituencies and eyes on the history books, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have each carved out a piece of Manhattan on which to fasten their economic development visions, with one another's blessing. 
 Mr. Bloomberg has laid claim to the development of the far West Side. Mr. Pataki wants credit for the rebirth of Lower Manhattan. 
 The deal holds the opportunity for each man to secure a lasting political legacy involving some of the most prestigious and valuable real estate in the world, in a city that favors largeness and vision. 
 The deal became slightly more overt this week when Mr. Bloomberg served as master of ceremonies to announce plans to greatly expand the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and build a 75,000-seat stadium. 
 ''It is a fair to say that the governor has taken more of a lead on the World Trade Center site,'' said Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff. ''And the mayor has taken more of a lead'' with the nuts and bolts of developing the far West Side, he said. 
 Since before he ran for mayor, Mr. Bloomberg has been a proponent of creating housing and office space and generally revitalizing one of the last remaining corridors of Manhattan that development has forgotten, the neighborhood in the West 30's, from Ninth Avenue to the Hudson River. He has said on multiple occasions that he believes improving the Javits center will bring about all of that, while creating jobs and stimulating tourism.
 Governor Pataki, according to people who have worked closely with the governor on the issue, is focused on Lower Manhattan, specifically the site of the fallen World Trade Center, which he believes will bring international attention to the city, and by proxy, himself. He also is said to feel that he has been the continuous governmental link in the city since the terrorist attack of 2001, and has said on many occasions that the site -- along with the memory of the day -- has profound personal meaning for him. 
 While the two have not actually taken out a map and divided up the city with tiny push pins, their staffs have come to an agreement that each will do much of the work -- and, their aides hope, get the credit -- for their area of interest, said several people involved in both projects. 
 At a meeting last month between Mr. Pataki and several of his senior aides, Mr. Pataki said, ''I've made a deal with the mayor to support him on the West Side,'' according to an aide who attended the meeting. Part of that deal, the aide said, was that Mr. Bloomberg would give the governor a free hand in Lower Manhattan, which he has largely done since the earliest plans were discussed. 
 According to the aide in the meeting, Mr. Pataki urged his staff members -- some of whom were reluctant to get on board with the stadium plan for myriad complex reasons -- to get united behind the West Side projects. 
 And though both men attended the announcement of the stadium and Javits plans this week, it was Mr. Bloomberg who served as host. Mr. Pataki played the central role earlier this year to announce the plans for the memorial to World Trade Center victims in Lower Manhattan. 
 While Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Pataki are far from close friends -- they have clashed over everything from taxes to federal aid to the city -- they have put their differences behind them for mutual benefit to their own legacy projects. ''I think they really see each other as partners,'' Mr. Doctoroff said, a notion echoed by three aides to the governor.
 Sometimes, that can simply mean staying out of each other's way. Other times, it means lending significant material support and showing a public face of unity. In terms of developing the West Side, the state had to commit to significant financing, and expanding the Javits center requires state legislation, which the governor has already said he will support. 
 Stretching out the No. 7 train line to the far West Side, which is far from a fait accompli, and building on the Long Island Rail Road yards there require the acquiescence of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, an agency controlled by the governor. At the mayor's behest, Mr. Pataki also has freed up his chief economic development official, Charles A. Gargano, to help get things moving. 
 Mr. Pataki has spent far more time in meetings with the various interests in the Lower Manhattan site than Mr. Bloomberg, and he devotes far more of his speeches and other public remarks to discussing Lower Manhattan than the mayor.
 The mayor has helped the governor in small but significant ways, appointing minorities and women to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, deflecting criticism building against the governor that the board was too white and male.
 For several months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Mr. Pataki was largely in the shadow of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. But after Mr. Bloomberg took office, Mr. Pataki easily found a way to become front and center in the rebuilding process. The board charged with leading rebuilding -- the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation -- is an adjunct of the state, controlled by Mr. Pataki. 
 Further, he has been much more successful than the mayor at getting along with the more outspoken family members of those killed in the attack than Mr. Bloomberg, who has at times antagonized them. 
 Even in his remarks during this week's news conference, Mr. Pataki took pains to mention Lower Manhattan, too. 
 ''The governor considers it both an honor and an obligation to rebuild Lower Manhattan in honor of those we lost during the greatest attack on American soil,'' said Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman for the governor.Mr. Bloomberg's interest in the far West Side dates back to his involvement in luring the Olympics to the city. He was a board member and contributor to NY2012, Mr. Doctoroff's organization created to bring the Olympic Games to New York, and spoke about the issue during the mayoral campaign.Mr. Bloomberg has mentioned the convention center expansion idea in all three of his state of the city speeches. 
 Edward Skyler, the mayor's spokesman, said, ''There's no doubt that he has the longest personal involvement in the far West Side and that the transformation of this neglected area is going to be the backbone of the city's economic growth in the 21st century.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki with the master of ceremonies, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as they announced ambitious plans for developing the far West Side. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Rumbling Through History

BYLINE: By SARAH SLOBIN

 BODY:
By 1850 the island of Manhattan was bottom-heavy. People were packed into its southern tip, and a population explosion was adding wave upon wave of immigrants. The city needed new transit networks to ease crowds on its clogged streets and to expand into open land to the north and south. Subways won out over elevated trains, and New Yorkers have been riding in a hole in the ground ever since. Here are some of the high points and low of a system riders love, hate and depend on every day. SARAH SLOBIN

Tammany Hall collected tribute from streetcars, and Boss Tweed was an el fan. This didn't stop Alfred Ely Beach, an inventor and publisher, from trying to outwit the powers that be. In 1870 he unveiled his ''pneumatic subway,'' an underground tube secretly constructed under lower Broadway in the guise of building a mail system. The tunnel was 312 feet long and 9 feet wide, and the waiting room had a grand piano and a goldfish tank. The train was blown end to end by a giant fan system, and the public loved it. Though Beach fought to expand it, Tammany Hall thwarted him at every turn. With the Panic of 1873, money dried up, and the subway, at least as Beach envisioned it, closed after four years. HEADLINE: Bumps Along the Rails

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
AS you ride the A train or the 2 train or any other line on the New York subway, you may want to mull an essential but mostly forgotten fact, one that could be posted aboard every train as a civics lesson. 
 It is this: Many of the lines exist because eight decades ago, a mayor and a newspaper publisher despised the existing transit companies. The city built those lines not to complement the older ones, but to compete with them -- in fact, to bankrupt them. It worked, which is why New Yorkers ended up with overlapping transit service in some areas, and no service in others. 
 While the subway is rightly praised as the life force of the city, it is equally true that its past and present have been shadowed by politics, rivalries, grudges, accidents, demagoguery and decisions that were just plain dumb.
 Most squabbles were about money, and they go a long way toward explaining the subway's central failing: wide swaths of the city have no service. With a few small exceptions, the system has not been expanded since 1941; the demolition of elevated lines means the city has less transit rail service now than it had then.
 ''If you go to any of the major European systems, or Tokyo or Seoul, historically, they have not just kept the system in good order, they have expanded it to keep pace with the city's growth,'' said Peter Derrick, a historian and the author of ''Tunneling to the Future: The Story of the Great Subway Expansion That Saved New York'' (New York University Press, 2001). ''What sets New York apart is the failure to do that, the failure at times to even keep it in good order, the inability to come to terms with who will pay for things over the long run.''
 More than any of the systems abroad, he added, New York's is expected to pay for itself through passenger fares, rather than government investment.
 The dark side of the subways predates the system itself. Construction of the first tunnel was delayed by more than a decade -- Boston beat New York to it as a result -- by disputes over what would get built, by whom, where and with whose money.
 ''Transit is political,'' said Gene Russianoff, who, as staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, has spent more than two decades lobbying public officials for money. ''It's been as bare-knuckles as any aspect of life in New York, going back to Boss Tweed.''
 The original subway planners also became combatants in one of the defining economic struggles of the industrial age, over the future of a new commodity, electricity. Thomas Edison championed direct current electricity, while George Westinghouse and Nikola Tesla promoted alternating current, and they battled for years to win adherents. 
 The Interborough Rapid Transit Company, the IRT, sided with Edison, a mistake that New Yorkers are still paying for. Within a few years, alternating current became the world's standard. So to this day the subway system buys power from the grid, available only as alternating current, and must convert it to direct current before pumping it into the third rail. 
 Early business and political rivalries led to another fundamental blunder. The subway today remains two separate systems -- the numbered lines in one, the lettered lines in the other -- whose trains, tunnels and platforms are incompatible.
 But it is money, or its lack, that has shaped the system for much of the last century. The system lives in a constant state of tension among three sets of expenses: daily operations, regular replacement of old equipment, and expansion. The debates over balancing these expenses, involving fare increases and government subsidies, often become political brawls. 
 In the late 19th century, the fare on the elevated and street-level trains that plied the city was a nickel. When the subway came along, the fare was a nickel, too. And for decades after, through wars and inflation, the political leaders who controlled the fare refused to raise it.
 By the end of World War I, the city's two transit rail companies, the IRT and the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, were losing money and seeking a fare increase, and the BRT entered bankruptcy, emerging a few years later as the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company, or BMT. Yet the city's populist mayor, John F. (Red Mike) Hylan, rebuked ''grasping transportation monopolies'' and defended the nickel fare as a birthright. Mr. Hylan's principal backer, William Randolph Hearst, blared this view from his newspapers. (They were less than impartial. Decades earlier, the BRT's forerunner had fired Hylan from his job as a train engineer; Hearst saw attacks on the transit companies as a good way to sell papers.) 
 Hylan called for a new, city-owned system to be named the Independent, or IND, which is the origin of many of today's lettered lines. Rather than push the system into fresh terrain that needed service, like eastern Queens, he placed lines where they would compete with the IRT and BMT.
 By World War II, both of the older companies had collapsed and the city had taken them over and merged the three systems. But city control was no panacea, especially with the fare still a nickel. The first fare increase, to a dime, did not occur until 1948, 44 years after the subway opened. By then, the country was in thrall to the automobile, and investment in mass transit dwindled. Basic maintenance was neglected; ridership and revenues plummeted, and transit strikes in 1966 and 1980 did not help matters. Anyone who lived in the city in the early 80's remembers when the subways meant derailments, fires, graffiti and crime.
 New York State came to the rescue with billions of dollars starting in 1982, but in the last decade the state and the city have retreated from capital spending. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has an ambitious list of projects under way, including work for the long-delayed Second Avenue subway, but the agency's heavy reliance on borrowing, in the absence of government aid, has some financial watchdogs worried. 
 Politicians have always promised new service that nobody could or would finance. Both the 1913 plan that greatly expanded the system, and Hylan's 1922 IND initiative, were never completely realized. But the Second Avenue subway reigns as an icon of noncompletion, like the Cathedral of St. John the Divine or Gilbert Stuart's portrait of George Washington. Voters approved bonds for it in 1951, and demolition of the Third Avenue el in Manhattan a few years later was justified partly by arguing that a Second Avenue line was imminent. New York City Transit spends millions of dollars each year just to maintain the unused bits of tunnel it has dug.
 So what will become of the Second Avenue line? Mr. Russianoff, 50, replies with a question of his own: ''In my lifetime? Depends on the politicians.''

HEADLINE: Georgians Anxiously Watch New Leader

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, March 22 

 BODY:
It is democracy in a china shop aggressive televised arrests, new limitations on the press, a rushed constitutional amendment to concentrate presidential power, a headlong confrontation with a rebellious local strongman.
Two months into his term, Georgia's new democratically elected president, Mikhail Saakashvili, is bulling ahead with all the energy that drove out his predecessor, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in a popular uprising in November. 
 His supporters in the United States and Europe, who are heavily financing his government and have a stake in its success, are crossing their fingers that he will not push things too far. Human rights groups have begun to warn of a tendency toward one-man rule. 
 A highly intelligent and self-confident American-trained lawyer, Mr. Saakashvili, 36, had been known as something of a rabble rouser when he was in the opposition. Many people say he is just the man Georgia needs to shake this broken nation back to life.
 The corrupt mafia chieftains who control much of the economy must quickly learn who is boss, the government must pull itself together and start providing services, taxes must be collected, salaries and pensions must be paid, foreign investment must grow.
 Political analysts say Mr. Saakashvili may have a six-month window of time before the momentum for change slows and before Georgia loses the attention of foreign donors, including both governments and private organizations, notably the Open Society Institute founded by the billionaire George Soros. 
 ''We must move swiftly to take advantage of political support,'' Mr. Saakashvili said a month ago during a visit to Washington, where he met with President Bush and won promises of support. 
 The United States is heavily invested in Georgia because of its strategic location on Russia's southern border and because of a major oil pipeline that crosses its territory and is scheduled to open next year.
 A growing number of critics, though, say that the new president is exploiting his popularity to cut legal corners, violate human rights and silence opposition views, and that Georgia could find itself back in the hands of an autocratic leader. It is unlikely that a new Parliament, to be elected Sunday, will rein in his power. Opposition parties are so broken and demoralized that they may be shut out of the legislature altogether.
 The constitutional amendment, pushed through an obedient Parliament with little public discussion, has created a superpresidential system similar to that in today's Russia, where the chief executive dominates all branches of power.
 ''It's a very scary system,'' said Tinatin Khidasheli, a human rights lawyer. ''The system is absolutely unbalanced and depends on the good will of the president. We just hope Saakashvili will not use all the powers in the Constitution because if he tries, he could easily become a dictator.''
 Last month, Koba Davitashvili, a close associate of Mr. Saakashvili, resigned as leader of the governing party to protest the president's concentration of power and pressure on news organizations. 
 For now, though, Mr. Saakashvili remains a national hero.
 ''This is a very critical moment in Georgian history and I think the majority of Georgians support the measures carried out by the government,'' said George Khutsishvili, chairman of the International Center on Conflict and Negotiation, a local policy institute. 
 ''These are temporary measures,'' he added. ''When the government is in power only several months we should give them a chance to consolidate power and stabilize the situation. That's the first step.''
 The most aggressive and visible of the president's actions has been the arrests of a stream of powerful people accused of corruption. Several arrests have been shown on television, sometimes with the smashing of doors and waving of guns. 
 The strong-arm tactics and emerging reports of torture have drawn criticism from local and foreign human rights groups. Critics also say the government seems to be picking and choosing its targets, sometimes for political reasons.
 The president says he is sending a message. ''The era of Shevardnadze, when lawlessness reigned, is over,'' he said. ''If anyone thinks that I am joking, they are mistaken.'' 
 His riskiest move was to challenge the chieftain of the renegade province of Ajaria, who has a private army and has withheld hundreds of millions of dollars in customs fees and taxes. After blockading the province for four days last week, Mr. Saakashvili announced that he had solved the problem. For now, though, he seems to have gained little except a promise to allow the parliamentary election to proceed in Ajaria.
 His headlong approach was characteristic of his style, and the vagueness of its results has not enhanced his image.
 Mr. Saakashvili has won praise for streamlining government by cutting the number of ministries. His new cabinet, though, seems something of a gamble. It is largely drawn from civil society groups and other supporters of his opposition movement. Many ministers have little administrative experience, and some are in their 20's or 30's. 
 The loyalty of news organizations to the president has also affected their vigor. The support of major television stations was crucial to Mr. Saakashvili's rise to power, and they now seem to operate almost as part of his government team. 
 The two most freewheeling and popular political talk shows have been taken off the air, and commentary has become tamer. Journalists at a station critical of the president say they have received threats and warnings. Last month, they marched down a major avenue carrying a coffin that they said symbolized the death of a free press. 
 ''So now Georgia really does lack an independent, free and strong media, which was one of Georgia's advantages and one of the major driving forces for the revolution,'' said Archil Gegeshidze, a leading political analyst.

HEADLINE: From a Bohemian on Broadway To a Prince in the Opera House

BYLINE: By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
WELL before Baz Luhrmann came calling, Jesus Garcia had been warned. ''A friend,'' Mr. Garcia says, harking back to late 2001, ''I won't say her name, but in charge of a very big company in the classical-music business, told me that there was about to be a production of 'La Boheme' on Broadway. 'I hear they're looking for you,' she said. 'Don't do it.' ''
 But he did, and like the other nine singers who shared the opera's four principal roles, he has a special Tony Award to show for it. Which of the Three Tenors ever got one of those?
 One morning early this month, with spring in the air, Mr. Garcia, a lithe 27-year-old, is telling his story on a bench in Rittenhouse Square. Born in Houston, he pronounces his first name the Spanish way -- hay-SOOS -- but no longer writes it with an accent. The bohemian shag he wore as Puccini's penniless poet Rodolfo has been cropped to a uniform fraction of an inch, the black salted with precocious white. 
 His alma mater, just steps away, is the Academy of Vocal Arts, which advertises ''world-class training for opera singers.'' Home is a sun-drenched studio apartment in Center City, monastically vacant but for a mattress, a yoga mat, a small bookcase, a picture of a blond Jesus swathed in Indian silks (his forehead bearing a red dot) and an iBook, which stores, among other things, the demo of pop songs he is writing.
 A major point of reference is the pop star and self-styled ''anti-celebrity'' Bjork, for whom Mr. Garcia expresses ''complete admiration as an artist, poet and musician.'' Mr. Garcia paints and draws and is in the process of founding a theatrical production company called Brahmin Industries. His new Web site, rockthejesus.com, should be up and running any minute.
 So has Mr. Garcia kissed opera goodbye? Not at all. On Saturday he returns to the Washington National Opera, where he made his debut in September as Alfred, the singing teacher with the aphrodisiac high notes in Johann Strauss's ''Fledermaus.'' Now he is playing Don Ramiro, the Prince Charming of Rossini's retelling of the Cinderella story, ''La Cenerentola.'' Contrary to many dire predictions, there is life after Baz.
 With all due respect to its superb theatrical values, the Luhrmann ''Boheme'' raised definite musical issues. It used a severely reduced orchestra, supplemented with synthesizers. The singers, despite their operatic training and the modest capacity of the Broadway house, used microphones.
 One rising tenor in the audience, already familiar in principal lyric roles at the Metropolitan Opera, squirmed through a performance in sympathetic agony. The sheer emotionalism of the music and the heavy performing schedule, he thought, were a recipe for disaster.
 At intermission, he was blue-lipped with indignation. Young singers, he insisted, should sound fresh, not so old and frayed. They were being shredded, he said, and once their voices were used up, there would be no way back.
 Mr. Garcia was well aware of what people were saying. ''I knew the buzz,'' he says now. But he seemed more at home in his part than most of his colleagues. Of Mr. Luhrmann's three Rodolfos -- the others were Alfred Boe, an Englishman, and David Miller, an American -- only he displayed the sensuous Latin timbre and instinctive pathos Puccini's writing implies. Was he in over his head? Very possibly. Yet not altogether out of his element.
 What draws a boy in Houston to opera? In Mr. Garcia's case, not the Met radio broadcasts. Not a performance at the Houston Grand Opera. Certainly not the influence of his parents (his mother a banking executive, his father a carpenter and teacher of vocational arts), whom he characterizes as ''anti-stage-parents,'' more apt to discourage an economically precarious career in the arts than to promote it.
 What Mr. Garcia wanted to be, growing up, was a pop star like Michael Jackson and Madonna, whose videos held him spellbound.
 ''They were just such fascinating people,'' he says, ''and what they put on the screen was great music theater, instant gratification.'' In high school, he started taking private voice lessons. Then he heard a CD of Luciano Pavarotti and was enraptured by the sheer sound.
 ''Another tenor,'' Mr. Garcia says. ''I thought I could do that.''
 A second revelation followed at the movie ''Philadelphia.'' ''Maria Callas was singing 'La mamma morta,' '' Mr. Garcia recalls. ''It fascinated me emotionally. It ripped me to shreds.''
 At the Academy of Vocal Arts, Mr. Garcia found his niche in Mozart and the bel canto repertory, where purity of line and nimble articulation matter more than a big sound. One day he was perplexed to hear a mentor say that he seemed to have become more preoccupied with technique than with art.
 ''I didn't think that was true,'' Mr. Garcia says now, ''but maybe I'd gotten robotic. And maybe he was trying to get me to take the next step.''
 What is true is that by temperament Mr. Garcia gravitates toward the heavier emotional weather of verismo, the style associated with Puccini and other Italian composers around the turn of the 20th century.
 ''In bel canto,'' he says, ''what happens is this: You get in position and basically say to the audience, 'Now I'll sing one emotion for five pages.' In verismo, it's like a movie. The music keeps changing. What I like is realism onstage, not costumes, not pageantry.
 ''I love all the things I can't sing. So for now, I'm singing only bel canto, so as not to mess up my chances. I don't want to compromise what I've worked so hard to build.''
 ''La Boheme,'' in other words, was a calculated risk, motivated in large part by the opportunity to work with Mr. Luhrmann, whose movie of ''Romeo and Juliet'' had struck Mr. Garcia with the force of revelation. ''It was the first time I could follow Shakespeare without missing a beat,'' he said, ''without feeling that it was over my head.''
 Even so, Mr. Garcia stipulated from the beginning that he would sing only two shows a week. And alone among the original three Rodolfos, he dropped out before the end of the Broadway run. ''It was time,'' he says. ''My voice was tired.''
 But according to Mr. Luhrmann, who jokingly called him Young Pavarotti, Mr. Garcia had grown tremendously. ''What was a joy working with Jesus,'' Mr. Luhrmann said recently, ''was to see him go from virtually no grasp of the dramatic process to embracing it fully. I think he's a very good example of the way vocal growth can align with development as a dramatic player.''
 To rehabilitate himself in the eyes of the opera world, Mr. Garcia entered the Operalia competition, sponsored by Placido Domingo, and won.
 Opera fans are forever debating singers' repertory choices, and the high percentage of break-out talents who crash and burn suggests the difficulty of matching their gifts to the demands of their profession. Mr. Domingo, at 63, is the incontestable champion on that score, still juggling some of the most demanding tenor roles with conducting gigs and the general directorships of not only the Washington National Opera but also the Los Angeles Opera.
 ''I first heard Jesus Garcia a couple of years ago, before he sang 'Boheme' on Broadway, and was immediately impressed by his voice,'' Mr. Domingo said recently from Moscow. ''Later, everyone who heard him at Operalia was impressed with the quality of his voice and his artistry. I think he can become one of the really exciting singers of his generation if he doesn't let himself be rushed into roles which might come later in his career. Something tells me that he has analyzed his career path very well.''
 The offers of Alfred and Don Ramiro in Washington, Mr. Domingo added, had as much to do with Mr. Garcia's personality as with vocal considerations, and Mr. Garcia clearly entertains offers in the same spirit. Other tenors of comparable profile would snap up the part of Rossini's Count Almaviva in ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' or Mozart's Don Ottavio in ''Don Giovanni.'' Having sung both in school, Mr. Garcia professes no further interest in the Mozart role (''boring'') and has turned down an offer from a major European house for the Rossini.
 Don Ramiro strikes him as ''more heroic and more lyric'' than Almaviva. ''You can really sing it,'' he says. ''It's a very masculine role, not something foppish and jokey.''
 Among the legacies of his spell on Broadway is a contract with a Hollywood agent for film and television work. What will come of it is anyone's guess, as are his prospects as a pop artist. But one thing Mr. Garcia promises never to do is the sort of operatic pop that has made millionaires of tenors like Andrea Bocelli and Josh Groban.
 ''I'm definitely playing both sides of the fence,'' Mr. Garcia says. ''And whatever the medium, whatever I do, I want to pursue it full force. There's very little I don't want to do. But I'm not into joining the two cultures at the expense of either one.''

LENGTH: 1673 words

HEADLINE: American Dreams, Not Made In the U.S.A.

 BODY:
STEVE JAMES won't like being called the ''Hoop Dreams'' guy, but there it is: that beloved 1994 documentary about two high school basketball players in Chicago, which won practically every major award except the Oscar, remains his best-known work.
 Since then he's made several feature films, including ''Prefontaine'' (1997), about the runner Steve Prefontaine; and another highly personal documentary project, ''Stevie,'' covering more than four years in the life of a troubled young man for whom Mr. James had once served as a Big Brother. 
 Now he has an even more labor-intensive project coming to the screen: ''The New Americans,'' a three-night, seven-hour documentary (culled from 1,100 hours of film) that begins tomorrow at 9 p.m. Eastern on PBS stations. It follows five immigrant tales -- families from Nigeria, Mexico, India and the West Bank and a pair of Dodgers farmhands from the Dominican Republic -- for three to four years, both before and after coming to America. Mr. James worked with other producers, including Gordon Quinn, a partner on ''Hoop Dreams,'' and Gita Saedi, and six other directors. He spoke with Mike Hale recently by phone from his Chicago office.

MIKE HALE -- ''The New Americans'' often feels like a companion piece to ''Hoop Dreams.''

STEVE JAMES -- I think in some ways, stylistically, it's in the same vein. We started with people in their country of origin, before they become immigrants, and not only get to know them in their own countries but also hear of their dreams and expectations for America. In ''Hoop Dreams'' you met these kids in their neighborhoods as dreamers, they were dreaming of greatness and of getting to the N.B.A. We started with people at a turning point, where their lives are about to change in dramatic ways.

HALE -- Where did you get the idea for such a large project on the subject of immigration?

JAMES -- Oddly enough, it came to me back in 1994, during the final stages of ''Hoop Dreams.'' It was a time when Patrick Buchanan was talking very publicly about the need to close the borders with Mexico. And there was a lot of discussion in Congress about welfare reform and the impact of immigrants on our economy. I'm a pretty liberal guy, but I recognized that I was sort of unsettled by a lot of this and wasn't sure how I felt about immigration and about issues of undocumented workers coming from Mexico. I think I shared a lot of the same questions that a lot of Americans had at that time.
 And the other thing is, I was doing a lot more traveling because of ''Hoop Dreams.'' And I'm one of these guys that talks to cabbies. And invariably in big cities, cabbies are immigrants. And I would strike up these conversations with cabbies about where they're from, why they came here, what they used to do back home. And invariably they had fascinating stories that I thought to be quite revealing of America today.
 And so it struck me -- if in ''Hoop Dreams'' we were trying to look at the American dream through the eyes of inner-city black families and these two boys aspiring to make it, it would be really interesting to do something akin to that with contemporary immigrants and look at the American dream and the American myth of the melting pot through their eyes. And in the process, inquire into something that I felt a need to understand better.
 This is not in the series, but it was revealing to me: at one point, in the Nigerian story, Israel was talking about his dreams of earning an M.B.A. and being successful in business. And I said, ''Oh, is that your American dream?'' And he looked at me and said, ''No, that's my Nigerian dream.''

HALE -- The sense of being torn -- between homeland and America, between family and America, between culture and America -- is so central to the film. Did you know going in that that was your story?

JAMES -- No. You'd have to ask the other filmmakers directly, because some of them were much more sophisticated about this than I was. Indu Krishnan is from India; Carlos Aparicio and Susana Aikin were born in Spain and are immigrants themselves; Renee Tajima-Pena is first-generation Japanese-American. My immigrant roots are more deeply buried. Having said that, I was surprised. Part of the myth of the immigrant experience is that immigrants come to America and embrace this new country wholeheartedly, and make a break with their past. And I think there was a time in our history when that was more true than it is today. Many of our subjects felt that in leaving the familiar behind and the tightknit communities and families they came from, and coming to America, that America is not a place where you can find that very easily.

HALE -- There are scenes where the camera is inside the room as the Mexican family, or the Palestinian couple, are trying to get visas. Did you worry about the filming influencing events?

JAMES -- It would have been so easy for the consulate, particularly in the Mexico story, to make a show to the cameras and kind of slide them through and look like heroes. And they didn't. I'm actually, frankly, more amazed at how little impact we do have. Israel, the Nigerian refugee, still struggled to get a decent job in America; Naima, the Palestinian, still struggled to get employed when she first got here. You can run down the list of all the things that happened to these people in this series, and you see some pretty amazing things, turns of events with the cameras rolling, that you would think, if someone was really trying to be shrewd about it, it wouldn't have happened that way.
 There's no question that filming on some level influences events. I think the more profound influence, at least in the work we've done, is that by filming you're giving your subjects an opportunity to reflect on their lives. You're there, you're asking them to think about what they're doing and where they've come and where they're headed. And that's not something we normally do. To the extent that it makes people think, it may affect some decisions they make. But it's more of a byproduct of the almost therapeutic process that goes on in these kinds of documentaries.

HALE -- I'm guessing that you basically thought you were done, at least with the filming, before Sept. 11 happened. It seems as if it must have had a profound impact on how you put the series together, on how you thought about the world you were putting it into.

JAMES -- Certainly it was winding down. It's interesting. Once we got our bearings, we wondered whether this happening so late was going to present a real problem -- whether we should keep filming for a lot longer, which we couldn't afford, whether it would in some ways make what had come before seem less important. But we realized that the opposite would be true. In the wake of 9/11 a lot of people in the news media rushed out to get the temperature of the people, to take the pulse. And we had already been deeply into these people's lives for years. And I think that it allowed us to not do the obvious thing. We talked about trying to ask all our subjects what they felt about 9/11 and including that at the end of the film. And we did it with some of our subjects, but we decided, no, we're just going to keep telling the story.

HALE -- What's it like embarking on something like this, which is an aesthetic commitment, a business commitment and a commitment of years of your life? Which you do over and over again.

JAMES -- I've done it now three times between ''Hoop Dreams,'' ''Stevie'' and this series. This is hard in a lot of ways and it requires an inordinate amount of patience and determination on the part of a lot of people because, often as not, at a certain point you're not sure where the money's going to come from to finish it. You just know that, one way or the other, we have to finish it.
 But there's nothing quite as thrilling and eye-opening and, frankly, moving as following people's lives like this. You feel like you're living inside their lives, and inside this kind of elaborate novel where the story is unfolding and you don't know the end. I never believe writers when they say they don't know where their story's going and they let their characters lead them. But maybe it's true because it certainly is true with us.

HALE -- The series is clearly made from a liberal, pro-immigration point of view -- the melting pot is good -- that may not sit well with all viewers.

JAMES -- But you know, I think there's so much in the series that . . . well, it'll be interesting to see what the critical response is. The series has already played in the Netherlands and in Australia. And the theme of those reviews was, America presents itself to the world as the melting pot, the nation of immigrants. And this series shows you that it's not that way. Israel is a man who's full of optimism coming out of the refugee camp. But he proceeds to be beaten down through the course of the series. Anjan comes, has a job, loses a job, is not successful and is forced to send his wife and child back to India. Jose ends up out of baseball. Hatem and Naima buy a house, but I don't know. It's kind of a bittersweet end to that story. And then in the Mexico story they end up going to work in the fields of California. As their neighbor says, they're actually going the opposite direction of the way people in Mexico dream of going, which is starting in the fields and getting to the factories. So I don't know. Frankly, we worried more that people would see the series as a downer.

HALE -- You've made a few dramatic features. Is that something you plan to do more of?

JAMES -- I'd like to do more of those. And I'd love to do something that doesn't have a sports theme and that doesn't have to be a true story. I've kind of been pigeon-holed. In Hollywood, if you make a successful film, whether narrative or nonfiction, they want you to do the same thing.

HALE -- Any other projects kicking around?

JAMES -- Well, I wrote a script on Roberto Clemente. I got paid to write it some years ago. And that project has been revived. There's a hope that can happen.

HEADLINE: True but Strange

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY. 
Randy Kennedy, a reporter for The Times, is the author of ''Subwayland,'' a collection of his Tunnel Vision columns, published last month by St. Martin's Griffin.

 BODY:
OVER the next several months, as the centennial of the subway's opening approaches, New Yorkers will hear a lot about the most momentous dates in the long and fascinating life of their mass transit system. 
 Commemorating these events -- the first train from City Hall to Harlem; the deadly Malbone Street wreck; the unification of the subway system under city control; the transit strikes -- is a little like looking through family pictures of weddings and bar mitzvahs. They are the milestone events. But in any life that stretches over a century, there are also countless little moments, the minor triumphs, epiphanies and turning points that are almost forgotten. 
 Think of what follows as the unauthorized chronology of the subway, a baker's dozen of its most underappreciated moments:

First Successful Baby Carriage Expedition
(April 1906)
 An article in The New York Times proclaims almost breathlessly: ''The fourteen-months-old baby of John Royalson, a clerk in a Chambers Street hardware store in East New York, made street railroad history in Manhattan yesterday.'' Apparently the parents of baby Royalson manage to get his carriage into the subway on their way home from Central Park, to the astonishment of everyone on the train. The ride ends at the Brooklyn Bridge ''when the Royalsons, escorted by an admiring throng, walked triumphantly through the station'' on their way to catch a trolley.

Introduction of the Turnstile
(June 1906)
 Subway officials announce the installation of the first turnstile at the 110th Street station. Fears spread that ticket choppers, the men who collect the paper predecessor of the token from passengers, will lose their jobs. An official assures workers that turnstiles will not replace them: ''It is absurd to suppose that we can get along with fewer men than we now have.'' (By 1921, turnstiles are replacing ticket choppers all over the system, although there are still some kinks to work out with the turnstile. One prototype has long arms that trap passengers until they pay. ''This type did not prove satisfactory,'' The Times said, ''because it invited considerable congestion when fat passengers sought to make the passage.'')

Emergence Of Subway Buffs
(July 1921)
 Subway workers report that they have begun to notice oddly enthusiastic people who ride the subway all day with no particular destination in mind. They refer to these people as ''joy riders'' or ''buffs.'' An article in The Times describes the buffs this way: ''This type of joy rider gets on a train, rides to its terminal, crosses the platform to another train and walks clear to its front end and rides through to the end of the line.'' A conductor notes: ''I've put 'em off sometimes and they don't kick none. They just wait for another train.''

Crackdown on Subway Entertainment
(April 1935)
 James C. Shramm, 24, is arrested and sentenced to a day in jail for dancing with a fire ax in the track bed at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue. A northbound local was bearing down on him at the time. Mr. Shramm, an unemployed waiter and saxophone player, tells a judge he got the ax at a party in Queens and was simply taking it home.

Debut of Fake Nuns
(February 1948)
 The Better Business Bureau of New York announces that many women seen recently in the subway dressed as nuns and collecting alms are not, in fact, nuns. According to a report by the bureau, the ''nuns'' pay $2.50 a day to an ''unnamed organization'' for official-seeming church credentials, which they return at the end of their workday. An article in The Times added that the nuns ''formerly worked on a percentage basis'' but ''the organization found it was not getting its share and hence devised the day-to-day system.'' 

Red Menace at the Doors
(January 1955)
 Max Lerner, a subway conductor for 19 years, is fired from his job as a security risk because he refuses to answer questions about his suspected Communist affiliations. A Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn upholds the decision.

Pole-Vaulter Not Killed
(February 1955)
 The Rev. Robert E. Richards, an Olympic gold medalist in the pole vault (left), reports that he has carried his 16-foot steel pole onto the IRT without incident. He had been unable to find a cooperative cabdriver. An article in The Times about Mr. Richards's subway ride reports: ''To travel companionably with an intractable, hingeless, 16-foot 'metal monster' takes rare qualities. A pole-vaulter not only has to be an exceptional athlete but he must also be a man of vast foresight, immense ingenuity, overwhelming persuasiveness and boundless good humor.'' The article quotes a subway worker's words to Mr. Richards: ''I don't know how you done it. But don't never do it again.'' 

New Kind of Rider Noticed
(July 1960)
 A pair of rhesus monkeys (above) are spotted hanging around in the subway downtown. One is caught; the second eludes capture for several days. A Times reporter describes one sighting: ''The monkey was standing on the northbound platform at the Rector Street station, as if waiting for a train, according to a passenger who made a report at the change booth.'' This second monkey was finally caught after startled pedestrians saw its fingers protruding through a sidewalk grate near Rector Street. 

Ski Service Added
(January 1964)
 A special nonstop train is operated briefly between Times Square and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, where a ski slope has been set up over Holes 15 through 18 of the park's golf course. Riders take their skis on board, and among the first to take the ski express are a couple from Houston, ''three boys from Long Island in search of girls,'' The Times said, ''and a 200-pound St. Bernard named Brandy, who has never saved anyone because he lives in an apartment house in Queens.'' 

Woman 'Buys' M.T.A. for $1
(June 1975)
 At a hearing, a director of the agency that runs the subway says the M.T.A. is so hard up that no private transit operator would want to buy it, perhaps because ridership has fallen to its lowest level since 1918, and 95 percent of the trains are marked with graffiti. He jokingly offers to sell the agency for a dollar. A woman in the audience whips out a dollar bill and announces: ''I'm taking you up. And now you're all fired.'' According to an account in The Times, she then lectured the board loudly for 15 minutes.

Subway Takes Star Turn
(February 1979)
 The movie ''The Warriors'' is released. Based loosely on ''Anabasis,'' Xenophon's epic tale of Greek mercenaries, the film tells the story of a street gang that must fight its way from the Bronx back to Coney Island, and much of the journey is made by subway. The movie is blamed for causing gang violence in theaters, but it also causes flashes of recognition from frustrated riders. One gang member in the movie, Vermin, is heard to complain: ''How much longer we gotta wait? We might be here forever. I'm sick of waiting for trains!''

Police Try Bold New Strategy
(July 1980)
 Subway police officers begin handing out cards to riders that read: ''Hello. This note is not meant to alarm you, but to inform you that the NYC Transit Police Dept. needs your help in preventing CRIME by not becoming a VICTIM.'' The card includes some helpful tips on how to avoid becoming one.

Boy Takes Train, Literally
(May 1993)
 Keron Thomas, 16 (below), posing as a subway motorman, takes an A train carrying hundreds of passengers on a 47-mile trip through the city until he triggers an emergency brake because he is speeding. It is the first known theft of a subway train, and the thief receives probation. He later says of his caper: ''It gave me a lot more self-confidence. It showed me that you can do whatever you want to do. You just got to put your mind to it.''

A selection of excerpts on March 28 from songs and literature about the subways, in the special issue on the system's hundredth anniversary, misstated the year for ''Take the A Train.'' It was 1941, not 1933.

HEADLINE: Vague on Leadership, Dangerous on the Attack

BYLINE: By GREG MYRE

DATELINE: JERUSALEM 

 BODY:
HAMAS, the principal Islamic Palestinian group staging suicide bombings and other attacks on Israeli targets, has a leadership structure that is kept vague to the general public. Its military wing works in secret, while its social services attract popular support in the absence of effective delivery of similar services by the Palestinian Authority.
 Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the group's founder and spiritual leader, was clearly the most important figure until he was killed last week in a rocket attack launched from an Israeli helicopter. 
 With him gone, Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, an advocate of uncompromising struggle with Israel, has been named leader of the group in the Gaza Strip, its main stronghold. There will be no new spiritual leader, and Khaled Mashaal, based in Syria, remains head of the Hamas political bureau, the top decision-making body. Mr. Rantisi is expected to lead operations in the West Bank as well as Gaza. 
 Hamas is considered much more disciplined, organized and dangerous to Israelis than two other Palestinian factions that carry out attacks, Islamic Jihad and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades. Islamic Jihad, like Hamas, has a religious base; the brigades group is linked to the more secular Fatah, Yasir Arafat's political base. Recently, the three factions appear to have cooperated on some attacks.
 Hamas draws its support among the poor and the religious, and the vast majority of Gazans fall into these groups. In Gaza, Hamas has been gaining ground on Fatah, though polls show Fatah still has more supporters there. The large Hamas network of social and welfare programs has been a key to winning supporters in three years of fighting, during which the Palestinian economy has collapsed.
 Hamas has been behind almost half of the more than 100 suicide bombings carried out by Palestinians since fighting began in September 2000. All the bombers except two started on their missions from the West Bank. In Gaza, Hamas has been behind regular rocket and mortar fire directed at Jewish settlements and at Israeli communities over the border. 
 Hamas operates on funds raised from private donors in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the Gulf, from other Muslim countries and from within the United States and Europe, which have tried to shut down the fundraising.
 GREG MYRE
